# Question: My brother and his wife are in prison for carrying out a large fraud scheme. Their 7 and 8 year old children have been living with me for the last 4 years. I want to become their Special Guardian to look after them permanently. How long will it be before I hear back from the court?
brother_in_prison = True
wife_in_prison = True
fraud_scheme = True
children_living_with_me = True
years_children_living_with_me = 4
want_to_become_special_guardian = True
court_response_time = None # This is the variable that answers the question
inter_results.doc_code:
#

What is a special guardian

#

You can apply to be a child’s special guardian when they cannot live with their birth parents and adoption is not right for them.

apply_for_special_guardian = True if cannot_live_with_birth_parents and adoption_not_right: special_guardian_possible = True #

You’ll be responsible for looking after the child until they’re 18 (unless the court takes your responsibility away earlier).

responsible_for_child_until_18 = True #

You’ll make all day to day decisions about the child, for example schooling and medical treatment. You do not have to discuss these decisions with the birth parents.

make_day_to_day_decisions = True do_not_have_to_discuss_with_birth_parents = True #

You’ll need to get the consent of everyone who has parental responsibility for the child before you make some important decisions, for example:

#
  • changing the child’s surname
    • #
  • putting the child up for adoption
    • #
  • taking the child abroad for more than 3 months
    • #
  • the child having surgery for reasons other than improving health, such as circumcision, sterilisation or cosmetic surgery
    • get_consent_for_important_decisions = True important_decisions = [ "changing child's surname", "putting child up for adoption", "taking child abroad for more than 3 months", "child having surgery for non-health reasons" ] #

    If you cannot get consent, you can ask the court to decide. Use the form ‘Make an application in existing court proceedings related to children’ (form C2).

    if cannot_get_consent: ask_court_to_decide = True use_form_C2 = True #

    After you apply

    #

    Within 10 days of receiving your application the court will send you a case number and a date for a meeting to set out:

    #
  • a timetable for your case
    • #
  • how it will be dealt with
    • #

    This meeting is called a ‘first directions hearing’.

    after_application_received = True court_sends_case_number_and_date = True meeting_to_set_out_details = True details_set_out = [ "timetable for case", "how it will be dealt with" ] #

    You must go to all hearings you’re told to unless the court excuses you. If you’re not able to go, contact the court office.

    must_attend_all_hearings = True if not_able_to_attend_hearing: contact_court_office = True

# Question: Me and my partner have been trying for a child for the past few years however with no luck. We have now decided we would like to adopt a child.. Are there any age requirements for the adopter when adopting a child in the UK?

unsuccessful_attempts = True
decided_to_adopt = True
age_requirements_for_adopter = None # This is the variable that answers the question
inter_results.doc_code:
#

Overview

#

To be adopted, a child must:

#
  • be under the age of 18 when the adoption application is made
    • #
  • not be (or have never been) married or in a civil partnership
    • if age_under_18 and not_married_or_in_civil_partnership: eligible_for_adoption = True #

    Who can adopt a child

    #

    You may be able to adopt a child if you’re aged 21 or over (there’s no upper age limit) and either:

    #
  • single
    • #
  • married
    • #
  • in a civil partnership
    • #
  • an unmarried couple (same sex and opposite sex)
    • #
  • the partner of the child’s parent
    • if age_21_or_over: if single or married or in_civil_partnership or unmarried_couple or partner_of_childs_parent: eligible_to_adopt = True #

    There are different rules for private adoptions and adoptions of looked-after children.

    different_rules_for_private_adoptions = True different_rules_for_looked_after_children_adoptions = True
inter_results.full_response:
#

You may be able to adopt a child if you’re aged 21 or over (there’s no upper age limit)

# Answer: yes

Overview

#

If you’re severely disabled as a result of a vaccination against certain diseases, you could get a one-off tax-free payment of £120,000. This is called a Vaccine Damage Payment.

Eligibility

#

  • pneumococcal infection

  • rotavirus

  • rubella (German measles)

  • tetanus

  • tuberculosis (TB)

    #

    • eligible_for_payment_meningitis_w = True #

Will I pay capital gains tax if I sell my current home in order to move into an inherited property?
inherited_home_location = "Sussex"
father_deceased = True
move_into_inherited_home = True
current_home_size = "small"
sell_current_home = True

inter_results.doc_code:
#

Overview

#

You don’t usually pay tax on anything you inherit at the time you inherit it.

tax_not_paid_on_inheritance = True #

You may need to pay:

#
  • Income Tax on profit you later earn from your inheritance, eg dividends from shares or rental income from a property
    • income_tax_on_profit_from_inheritance = True #
  • Capital Gains Tax if you later sell shares or a property you inherited
    • capital_gains_tax_on_sale_of_inherited_shares_or_property = True #
  • Inheritance Tax
    • inheritance_tax = True #

    Selling the property

    #

    You don’t pay Capital Gains Tax when you sell your home. You do pay it if you make a profit when you sell a property that isn’t your main home.

# Document: #

Overview

#

You and your partner may be able to take time off work if your child dies before they turn 18, or if you have a stillbirth after 24 weeks of pregnancy.

if child_dies_before_18 or stillbirth_after_24_weeks: eligible_for_leave_or_pay = True #

The death or stillbirth must have happened on or after 6 April 2020.

death_or_stillbirth_after_6_april_2020 = True #

You might be able to get leave, pay or both. You may be eligible for:

#
  • Parental Bereavement Leave
    • parental_bereavement_leave_eligible = True #
  • Statutory Parental Bereavement Pay
    • statutory_parental_bereavement_pay_eligible = True #

    There’s rules about when you can take your leave and pay and how to claim.

    rules_for_leave_and_pay = True #

    You can only claim Statutory Parental Bereavement Pay and Leave if you’re employed in England, Scotland or Wales.

    claim_in_england_scotland_wales = True #

    Parental Bereavement Leave

    #

    You can take 2 weeks’ leave from the first day of your employment for each child who has died or was stillborn if you’re eligible.

    if eligible_for_leave: parental_bereavement_leave = True #

    You can take:

    #
  • 2 weeks together
    • two_weeks_together = True #
  • 2 separate weeks of leave
    • two_separate_weeks = True #
  • only one week of leave
    • one_week_only = True #

    A week is the same number of days that you normally work in a week.

    week_same_number_of_days_as_normal_work_week = True #

    The leave:

    #
  • can start on or after the date of the death or stillbirth
    • leave_can_start_after_death_or_stillbirth = True #
  • must finish within 56 weeks of the date of the death or stillbirth
    • leave_must_finish_within_56_weeks = True #

    If you were the child’s parent or a parent’s partner

    #

    You may be eligible if at the time of the child’s death or stillbirth, you were:

    #
  • the child or baby’s parent - either biological, adoptive or parent of a child born to a surrogate
    • if child_or_baby_parent: eligible_for_leave_or_pay = True #
  • the partner of the child or baby’s parent
    • if partner_of_child_or_baby_parent: eligible_for_leave_or_pay = True #

    Biological parents of the child or baby will not be eligible for Parental Bereavement Leave and Statutory Parental Bereavement Pay after an adoption or parental order was made, unless there was a contact order in place.

#

Overview

#

    • income_tax_on_profit_from_inheritance = True #
  • Capital Gains Tax if you later sell shares or a property you inherited
    • capital_gains_tax_on_sale_of_inherited_shares_or_property = True #
  • Inheritance Tax
    • inheritance_tax = True #

    Inheritance Tax

    #

    The estate of the person who died usually pays Inheritance Tax. You may need to pay Inheritance Tax if the estate can’t or doesn’t pay it.

    #

    You may need to pay Inheritance Tax on a gift the person gave you in the 7 years before they died.

    #

    You may also need to pay it if your inheritance is put into a trust and the trust can’t or doesn’t pay.

    #

    If the will says the Inheritance Tax should be paid out of the assets you’ve inherited, the executor of the will or administrator of the estate will usually pay it.

Overview

#

Attendance Allowance helps with extra costs if you have a disability severe enough that you need someone to help look after you.

attendance_allowance_helps_with_extra_costs = True #

This guide is also available in Welsh (Cymraeg).

guide_available_in_welsh = True #

It’s paid at 2 different rates and how much you get depends on the level of care that you need because of your disability.

attendance_allowance_paid_at_2_rates = True amount_depends_on_level_of_care = True #

You could get £60 or £89.60 a week to help with personal support if you’re both:

if physically_or_mentally_disabled and state_pension_age_or_older: eligible_for_attendance_allowance = True #
  • physically or mentally disabled
    • physically_or_mentally_disabled = True #
  • State Pension age or older

    other_benefits_can_increase_with_attendance_allowance = True #

    You do not have to have someone caring for you in order to claim.

    no_caregiver_required_to_claim_attendance_allowance = True #

    If you do have a carer, they could get Carer’s Allowance if you have substantial caring needs.

    if have_carer_and_substantial_caring_needs: carer_eligible_for_carers_allowance = True #

    Attendance Allowance rates

    # Rate | Level of help you need # Lower rate - £60 | Frequent help or constant supervision during the day, or supervision at night # Higher rate - £89.60 | Help or supervision throughout both day and night, or you’re terminally ill if level_of_help_needed == "frequent help or constant supervision during the day, or supervision at night": attendance_allowance_rate = "lower rate - £60" elif level_of_help_needed == "help or supervision throughout both day and night, or you’re terminally ill": attendance_allowance_rate = "higher rate - £89.60" #

    if circumstances_change: can_get_different_rate = True must_report_change_of_circumstances = True #

inter_results.q_code:
# Question: Me and my partner recently adopted a child. It's almost three months now and still couldn't get along with the kid. I have started looking a counselling or a therapy for us and the kid. To pay for the counselling or therapy for the child and parents. Are there any funds available ?
adopted_child = True
time_since_adoption = "almost three months"
struggling_to_get_along_with_child = True
looking_for_counselling_or_therapy = True
funds_available_for_counselling_or_therapy = None # This is the variable that answers the question
inter_results.doc_code:
#

Overview

#

To be adopted, a child must:

#
  • be under the age of 18 when the adoption application is made
    • #
  • not be (or have never been) married or in a civil partnership
    • if age_under_18 and not_married_or_in_civil_partnership: eligible_for_adoption = True #

    Adoption Support Fund

    #

    You may be able to get funding from the Adoption Support Fund. It provides money for therapy for children and families to help improve relationships, confidence and behaviour. Your social worker can apply for you.

    adoption_support_fund_available = True funding_for_therapy_available = True #

    If you’re not happy with how the social worker has handled the application, complain to the council. If you’re not happy with the council’s response, contact the Adoption Support Fund team.

    if not_happy_with_social_worker_handling: complain_to_council = True if not_happy_with_council_response: contact_adoption_support_fund_team = True
inter_results.full_response:
#

You may be able to get funding from the Adoption Support Fund. It provides money for therapy for children and families to help improve relationships, confidence and behaviour. Your social worker can apply for you.

# Answer: yes

#

You get Child Benefit if you’re responsible for bringing up a child who is:

    Only one person can get Child Benefit for a child.

    only_one_person_get_child_benefit = True #

    It’s paid every 4 weeks and there’s no limit to how many children you can claim for.

    child_benefit_paid_every_4_weeks = True no_limit_on_number_of_children_claimed_for = True #

    This guide is also available in Welsh (Cymraeg).

    guide_available_in_welsh = True #

    By claiming Child Benefit:

    #
  • you can get National Insurance credits which count towards your State Pension
    • get_national_insurance_credits = True #
  • your child will automatically get a National Insurance number when they’re 16 years old
    • child_gets_national_insurance_number_at_16 = True #

    If you choose not to get Child Benefit payments, you should still fill in and send off the claim form.

    if choose_not_to_get_child_benefit_payments: still_fill_and_send_claim_form = True #

    If you or your partner earn over £50,000

    #

    You may have to pay back some of your Child Benefit in tax if your (or your partner’s) individual income is over £50,000.

    if individual_income_over_50000: may_have_to_pay_back_child_benefit_in_tax = True #

    If you or your partner earn over £50,000

    #

    You can get Child Benefit if your (or your partner’s) individual income is over £50,000, but you may be taxed on the benefit. This is known as the High Income Child Benefit Tax Charge.

    if individual_income_over_50000: get_child_benefit = True may_be_taxed_on_benefit = True high_income_child_benefit_tax_charge = True #

    If your partner’s income is also over £50,000 but yours is higher, you’re responsible for paying the tax charge. You need to fill in a Self Assessment tax return each tax year and pay what you owe.

    if partner_income_over_50000 and your_income_higher: responsible_for_paying_tax_charge = True fill_in_self_assessment_tax_return = True #

    Use the Child Benefit tax calculator to estimate how much tax you may have to pay.

    use_child_benefit_tax_calculator = True #

    Once you earn £60,000 you lose all of your benefit through tax.

    first_year_share_required = True #

    SPL_blocks = True SPL_one_go = True SPL_together_or_stagger = True #

    #

    • #

    • if meet_eligibility_criteria and give_notice_to_employers: eligible_for_SPL = True elegible_for_ShPP = True #

    For SPL to start

    #

    • if mother_or_person_getting_adoption_leave_return_to_work or binding_notice_given: SPL_can_start = True #

    start_SPL_while_partner_on_leave = True #

    binding_notice_and_SPL_plans_together = True #

inter_results.q_code:
# Question: I have completed a training to be an approved foster. I am getting a foster care allowance to help the cost of caring for a child. I get approximately £12000 per annum. What are my tax liability of the money I receive from foster care allowance and are there any tax relaxations?
completed_foster_training = True
approved_foster = True
foster_care_allowance = 12000
tax_liability = None # This is the variable that represents the tax liability of the foster care allowance
tax_relaxations = None # This is the variable that represents any tax relaxations that may apply
inter_results.doc_code:
#

Training and development

#

You need to complete the training, support, and development standards workbook within 12 months of being approved to foster.

complete_workbook_within_12_months = True #

Contact your fostering service to find out what other training and development is available. They should help you:

if contact_fostering_service: help_with_personal_development_plan = True participate_in_learning_and_development_sessions = True #

The Foster Carers’ Charter explains your rights as a foster parent.

foster_carers_charter_explains_rights = True #

You do not have a statutory right to time off work to care for foster children.

no_statutory_right_to_time_off_work = True #

If you’re fostering for adoption you’ll be entitled to adoption pay and leave from when the child comes to live with you.

if fostering_for_adoption: entitled_to_adoption_pay_and_leave = True #

If you’re considering fostering, find out about becoming a foster parent.

considering_fostering = True #

Tax arrangements

#

You should have registered as self-employed when you started to foster. You’ll need to file tax returns. Check with your fostering service what you need to do.

registered_as_self_employed = True file_tax_returns = True #

In your tax return, you’ll be able to claim:

#
  • a tax exemption of up to £10,000 per household
    • tax_exemption_up_to_10000 = True #
  • tax relief for every week you foster a child
    • tax_relief_for_each_week_of_fostering = True #

    This is known as qualifying care relief.

    qualifying_care_relief = True #

    You may be entitled to National Insurance credits, which count towards your State Pension.

    entitled_to_National_Insurance_credits = True #

    Tax exemption

    #

    In a tax year, households do not pay tax on the first £10,000 they earn from fostering. You’ll still pay tax on money you earn from a job or investment.

    tax_exempt_earnings_up_to_10000 = True #

    Tax relief

    #

    On top of the £10,000 exemption, you also get tax relief for every week (or part week) that a child is in your care. This means you do not have to pay tax on some of your earnings over £10,000.

    if child_age_under_11: tax_relief_per_child = 200 else: tax_relief_per_child = 250
inter_results.full_response:
#

In a tax year, households do not pay tax on the first £10,000 they earn from fostering. You’ll still pay tax on money you earn from a job or investment.

#

On top of the £10,000 exemption, you also get tax relief for every week (or part week) that a child is in your care. This means you do not have to pay tax on some of your earnings over £10,000.

# Answer: households do not pay tax on the first £10,000 they earn from fostering

#

Overview

#

You can help make or make decisions about someone’s property and money if they appointed you using an enduring power of attorney (EPA).

appointed_using_EPA = True #

The person who appointed you is called the ‘donor’ - you are their ‘attorney’.

donor_appointed = True #

Any decision you make on the donor’s behalf must be in their best interests.

decision_must_be_in_best_interests = True #

You’ll need to check if the donor’s given you specific instructions or guidance in the EPA document that will affect your responsibilities.

specific_instructions_in_EPA = True #

Only EPAs made and signed before October 1, 2007 can still be used. After that date donors had to make a lasting power of attorney (LPA) instead.

EPAs_before_October_2007_can_be_used = True #

Using the enduring power of attorney

#

You can start using an EPA at any time if the EPA is legal and the donor gives you permission.

can_start_using_EPA = True #

You’ll be responsible for helping the donor make decisions about their finances. Depending on their instructions you’ll help manage things like their:

if help_make_financial_decisions: manage_money_and_bills = True manage_bank_and_building_society_accounts = True manage_property_and_investments = True manage_pensions_and_benefits = True #

There may be other attorneys - if there are, check how the donor wants you to make decisions.

if other_attorneys_present: check_how_to_make_decisions_with_other_attorneys = True #

You must register the EPA when the donor starts to lose or has lost their mental capacity. This means they cannot make a decision at the time it needs to be made because of a mental impairment.

register_EPA_when_donor_loses_mental_capacity = True #

You must still involve the person in making decisions whenever possible and only make decisions on their behalf which are in their best interests.

involve_person_in_decisions_when_possible = True #

Check an enduring power is legal

#

You can only use an enduring power of attorney (EPA) if it was made correctly.

can_use_EPA_if_made_correctly = True #

Check that the EPA form was:

#
  • made when the donor was at least 18 and had the ability to make their own decisions (they had not lost ‘mental capacity’)
    • #
  • signed by the donor and a witness who was not one of the attorneys for the EPA
    • #
  • signed by all the attorneys
    • if EPA_form_correct: donor_was_at_least_18 = True donor_had_ability_to_make_decisions = True EPA_form_signed_by_donor_and_witness = True EPA_form_signed_by_all_attorneys = True #

    When the EPA was made you and any other attorneys had to be:

    #
  • 18 or over
    • #
  • not bankrupt - and have not been bankrupt since
    • if EPA_made: attorneys_18_or_over = True attorneys_not_bankrupt = True #

    Only EPAs made and signed before October 1, 2007 can still be used. After that date donors had to make a lasting power of attorney (LPA) instead.

    EPAs_before_October_2007_can_be_used = True #

    When there's more than one attorney

    #

    Check the enduring power of attorney (EPA) form to find out how many attorneys have been appointed.

    if more_than_one_attorney: check_EPA_form_for_number_of_attorneys = True #

    If there’s more than one attorney, check whether you must make decisions:

    #
  • separately or together (sometimes called ‘jointly and severally’), which means you can make decisions on your own or with other attorneys
    • #
  • together (sometimes called ‘jointly’), which means you and all the other attorneys have to agree on a decision
    • if more_than_one_attorney: if decisions_made_separately_or_together: make_decisions_separately_or_together = True if decisions_made_together: make_decisions_together = True #

    The donor may give instructions for you to make some decisions ‘jointly’ and others ‘jointly and severally’.

    if donor_gives_instructions: make_decisions_jointly_and_severally = True #

    Attorneys who are appointed jointly must all agree or they cannot make the decision.

    if attorneys_appointed_jointly: all_attorneys_must_agree_to_make_decision = True

Overview

#

donor_appointed_you = True #

Any decision you make on the donor’s behalf must be in their best interests.

decisions_must_be_in_best_interests = True #

You’ll need to check if the donor’s given you specific instructions or guidance in the EPA document that will affect your responsibilities.

specific_instructions_in_EPA = True #

EPAs_before_October_2007_can_be_used = True #

This guide is also available in Welsh.

guide_available_in_welsh = True #

#

#

What is a special guardian

#

You can apply to be a child’s special guardian when they cannot live with their birth parents and adoption is not right for them.

You’ll be responsible for looking after the child until they’re 18 (unless the court takes your responsibility away earlier).

responsible_for_child_until_18 = True #

You’ll make all day to day decisions about the child, for example schooling and medical treatment. You do not have to discuss these decisions with the birth parents.

make_day_to_day_decisions = True do_not_have_to_discuss_decisions_with_birth_parents = True #

You’ll need to get the consent of everyone who has parental responsibility for the child before you make some important decisions, for example:

#
  • changing the child’s surname
    • #
  • putting the child up for adoption
    • #
  • taking the child abroad for more than 3 months
    • #
  • the child having surgery for reasons other than improving health, such as circumcision, sterilisation or cosmetic surgery
    • get_consent_for_important_decisions = True important_decisions = [ "changing the child’s surname", "putting the child up for adoption", "taking the child abroad for more than 3 months", "the child having surgery for reasons other than improving health, such as circumcision, sterilisation or cosmetic surgery" ] #

    If you cannot get consent, you can ask the court to decide. Use the form ‘Make an application in existing court proceedings related to children’ (form C2).

    if cannot_get_consent: ask_court_to_decide = True form_C2_required = True #

    #

    if not_parent and over_18: can_apply_for_special_guardian = True #

    joint_claim_possible = True #

    #

    • already_legal_guardian = True #
  • the child lives with you because of a child arrangements order
    • child_lives_with_you_due_to_child_arrangements_order = True #
  • the child has lived with you for 3 of the past 5 years
    • child_lived_with_you_for_3_of_past_5_years = True #

  • you have the agreement of anyone named in a child arrangements order as someone who the child will live with
    • agreement_of_person_named_in_child_arrangements_order = True #
  • you have the agreement of all the people with parental responsibility for the child

  • you have the agreement of the local council, if the child is in care

    special_account_with_Court_Funds_Office = True #

    #

    A Court Funds Office account is called a ‘special account’ if the account holder has a deputy.

    special_account_if_account_holder_has_deputy = True #

    You’ll also get tax vouchers (for tax returns) with your April statement.

#

Training and development

#

You need to complete the training, support, and development standards workbook within 12 months of being approved to foster.

completion_deadline = 12 months #

Contact your fostering service to find out what other training and development is available. They should help you:

if contact_fostering_service: training_and_development_available = True #
  • with a personal development plan
    • personal_development_plan_available = True #
  • take part in learning and development sessions
    • learning_and_development_sessions_available = True #

    The Foster Carers’ Charter explains your rights as a foster parent.

    foster_carers_charter_explains_rights = True #

    You do not have a statutory right to time off work to care for foster children.

    no_statutory_right_to_time_off_work = True #

    If you’re fostering for adoption you’ll be entitled to adoption pay and leave from when the child comes to live with you.

    if fostering_for_adoption: entitled_to_adoption_pay_and_leave = True #

    If you’re considering fostering, find out about becoming a foster parent.

    considering_fostering = True #

    Minimum weekly allowance

    #

    The minimum allowance you’ll get depends on where you live and the age of the child you care for.

    minimum_allowance = True # | Age 0 to 2 | Age 3 to 4 | Age 5 to 10 | Age 11 to 15 | Age 16 to 17 # London | £155 | £158 | £177 | £201 | £235 # South East | £149 | £153 | £169 | £193 | £226 # Rest of England | £134 | £138 | £152 | £173 | £202 minimum_allowance_amounts = { "London": { "0 to 2": £155, "3 to 4": £158, "5 to 10": £177, "11 to 15": £201, "16 to 17": £235 }, "South East": { "0 to 2": £149, "3 to 4": £153, "5 to 10": £169, "11 to 15": £193, "16 to 17": £226 }, "Rest of England": { "0 to 2": £134, "3 to 4": £138, "5 to 10": £152, "11 to 15": £173, "16 to 17": £202 } } #

    These figures are for the tax year from 6 April 2021 to 5 April 2022. They’re updated every April.

    figures_for_tax_year = "6 April 2021 to 5 April 2022"

Overview

#

person_who_appointed_is_donor = True #

Any decision you make on the donor’s behalf must be in their best interests.

decisions_must_be_in_best_interests = True #

You’ll need to check if the donor’s given you specific instructions or guidance in the EPA document that will affect your responsibilities.

specific_instructions_in_EPA = True #

Only EPAs made and signed before October 1, 2007 can still be used. After that date donors had to make a lasting power of attorney (LPA) instead.

This guide is also available in Welsh.

guide_available_in_welsh = True #

    • EPA_made_when_donor_was_at_least_18 = True donor_had_ability_to_make_own_decisions = True #

    • attorneys_not_bankrupt = True

#

Overview

#

You may need to manage a Court Funds Office account for someone if you’re their property and affairs deputy and you’re authorised by the Court of Protection to look after money on their behalf.

if property_and_affairs_deputy and authorised_by_Court_of_Protection: manage_Court_Funds_Office_account = True #

Check the court order that appointed you as deputy - it tells you what you’re authorised to do.

check_court_order_for_authority = True #

You’ll need to apply on behalf of the person you’re deputy for to:

#
  • manage an account that was opened for them by court order, for example for money they received from a court case
    • #
  • open an account for them
    • if manage_account_opened_by_court_order or open_account_for_them: apply_on_behalf_of_person = True #

    They’ll get a special account with the Court Funds Office.

    special_account_with_Court_Funds_Office = True #

    Your responsibilities

    #

    The account belongs to the person you’re deputy for. You’re the only person who can manage it on their behalf.

    account_belongs_to_person = True only_deputy_can_manage_account = True #

    You must keep to your responsibilities as a deputy when you’re managing the account.

    keep_to_responsibilities_as_deputy = True #

    Check the court order that appointed you as deputy - it tells you the limits on what you can and cannot do with the account.

    check_court_order_for_limits = True #

    Apply

    #

    You need to apply to:

    #
  • open an account for someone
    • #
  • manage an account for someone
    • if apply_to_open_account or apply_to_manage_account: need_to_apply = True #

    You must be appointed by the Court of Protection as the person’s property and affairs deputy.

    appointed_by_Court_of_Protection = True #

    If your application is successful, you’ll be able to make withdrawals from the bank account that you run on behalf of the person whose affairs you manage.

    if application_successful: able_to_make_withdrawals = True #
  • Check the details on the court order that appointed you as deputy - you’ll need the date of the order and the case number.
    • check_details_on_court_order = True #
  • Fill in form CFO A to apply for authority to make withdrawals - give your bank account details and tick the ‘New details’ box.
    • fill_in_form_CFO_A = True #
  • Attach a copy of your bank statement (less than 3 months old) or a letter from your bank to confirm your bank account details.
    • attach_bank_statement_or_letter = True #
  • Fill in form CFO L to pay money in to the account at the same time as applying - attach a cheque made payable to the ‘Accountant General of the Senior Courts’.
    • fill_in_form_CFO_L = True #
  • Send forms and attachments together with a copy of the original court order that appointed you as deputy - it must have a seal. The address is on the forms.
    • send_forms_and_attachments_with_copy_of_court_order = True #

    You’ll get a letter from the Court Funds Office within 5 working days to confirm that you’re set up to manage the account.

    confirmation_letter_within_5_working_days = True #

    Your form will be returned if your application cannot be processed - you’ll be told what you can do to fix this.

    if application_cannot_be_processed: form_returned_with_instructions = True #

    Stop managing or close an account

    #

    A new deputy can take over management of the account if you stop being a deputy or die.

    if stop_being_deputy_or_die: new_deputy_can_take_over = True #

    You cannot hand over management of the account - only the Court of Protection can appoint a new deputy. The new deputy will then need to apply to manage the account.

    cannot_hand_over_management = True #

    You stop being a deputy

    #

    Tell the Court Funds Office in writing if you stop being a deputy - send a copy of the letter to the Office of the Public Guardian and Court of Protection.

    if stop_being_deputy: notify_Court_Funds_Office_in_writing = True send_copy_to_Office_of_Public_Guardian_and_Court_of_Protection = True

#

Overview

#

Special educational needs and disabilities (SEND) can affect a child or young person’s ability to learn. They can affect their:

if special_educational_needs_or_disabilities: #
  • behaviour or ability to socialise, for example they struggle to make friends
    • affect_behaviour_or_socialisation = True #
  • reading and writing, for example because they have dyslexia
    • affect_reading_and_writing = True #
  • ability to understand things
    • affect_ability_to_understand = True #
  • concentration levels, for example because they have ADHD
    • affect_concentration_levels = True #
  • physical ability
    • affect_physical_ability = True #

    Who to talk to

    #

    If you think your child may have special educational needs, contact the SEN co-ordinator, or ‘SENCO’ in your child’s school or nursery.

    if child_in_school_or_nursery: contact_SENCO = True #

    Contact your local council if your child is not in a school or nursery.

    if child_not_in_school_or_nursery: contact_local_council = True #

    Your local Information, Advice and Support (IAS) Service can give you advice about SEND.

    IAS_service_can_provide_advice = True #

    Support your child can receive

    #

    Your child may be eligible for:

    #
  • SEN support - support given in school, like speech therapy
    • SEN_support_possible = True #
  • an education, health and care (EHC) plan - a plan of care for children and young people aged up to 25 who have more complex needs
    • EHC_plan_possible = True #

    If you or your child got support before September 2014 this will continue until your local council changes it to an EHC plan.

    support_before_september_2014_continues = True #

    Children under 5

    #

    SEN support for children under 5 includes:

    #
  • a written progress check when your child is 2 years old
    • progress_check_at_2_years_old = True #
  • a child health visitor carrying out a health check for your child if they’re aged 2 to 3
    • health_check_at_2_to_3_years_old = True #
  • a written assessment in the summer term of your child’s first year of primary school
    • written_assessment_in_summer_term_of_first_year_of_primary_school = True #
  • making reasonable adjustments for disabled children, like providing aids like tactile signs
    • reasonable_adjustments_for_disabled_children = True #

    Nurseries, playgroups and childminders registered with Ofsted follow the Early Years Foundation Stage (EYFS) framework. The framework makes sure that there’s support in place for children with SEND.

    nurseries_playgroups_childminders_follow_EYFS_framework = True #

    Talk to a doctor or health adviser if you think your child has SEND but they do not go to a nursery, playgroup or childminder. They’ll tell you what support options are available.

    if child_has_SEND_but_not_in_nursery_playgroup_or_childminder: talk_to_doctor_or_health_adviser = True #

    Extra help

    #

    An education, health and care (EHC) plan is for children and young people aged up to 25 who need more support than is available through special educational needs support.

    #

    EHC plans identify educational, health and social needs and set out the additional support to meet those needs.

    EHC_plan_for_children_and_young_people = True

Overview

#

You can claim back 25p every time an individual donates £1 to your charity or community amateur sports club (CASC). This is called Gift Aid.

claim_gift_aid = True #

You must be recognised as a charity or CASC for tax purposes.

recognised_as_charity_or_CASC = True #

There are rules on which donations you can claim Gift Aid on.

rules_on_donations_for_gift_aid = True #

You can claim Gift Aid online - you should get your payment within 5 weeks.

claim_gift_aid_online = True payment_within_5_weeks = True #

What the donor needs to do

#

The donor must:

#
  • have paid at least as much in Income Tax or Capital Gains Tax in that tax year as you want to claim in Gift Aid
    • #
  • make a Gift Aid declaration that gives you permission to claim it
    • #

    If the donor has not made a declaration you may still be able to claim on cash donations of £30 or less, for example from a collection.

    donor_requirements_for_gift_aid = [ "paid at least as much in Income Tax or Capital Gains Tax as claimed in Gift Aid", "made a Gift Aid declaration" ] claim_gift_aid_on_cash_donations_of_30_or_less = True #

    What you can claim it on

    #

    You can claim Gift Aid on donations from individuals. The donor must:

    #
  • have paid the same amount or more in Income Tax or Capital Gains Tax in that tax year
    • #
  • make a Gift Aid declaration that gives you permission to claim it
    • #

    You must be recognised as a charity or community amateur sports club (CASC) to claim Gift Aid.

    claim_gift_aid_on_donations_from_individuals = True donor_requirements_for_gift_aid_on_donations_from_individuals = [ "paid the same amount or more in Income Tax or Capital Gains Tax in that tax year", "made a Gift Aid declaration" ] recognised_as_charity_or_CASC_to_claim_gift_aid = True #

    What you cannot claim it on

    #

    You cannot claim on donations:

    #
  • from limited companies
    • #
  • made through Payroll Giving
    • #
  • that are a payment for goods or services or made because your charity or CASC bought goods and services
    • #
  • where the donor gets a ‘benefit’ over a certain limit
    • #
  • of shares
    • #
  • from charity cards or of vouchers, for example Charities Aid Foundation (CAF) vouchers
    • #
  • of membership fees to CASCs
    • #
  • you got before you were a recognised charity or CASC

Overview

rules_on_donations_for_gift_aid = True #

You can claim Gift Aid online - you should get your payment within 5 weeks.

claim_gift_aid_online = True payment_within_5_weeks = True #

What the donor needs to do

The donor must:

#

Overview

#

The honours system recognises people who have:

#
  • made achievements in public life
    • achievements_in_public_life = True #
  • committed themselves to serving and helping Britain
    • committed_to_serving_and_helping_Britain = True #

    They’ll usually have made life better for other people or be outstanding at what they do.

    made_life_better_or_outstanding = True #

    actively_involved_for_nomination = True gallantry_awards_possible_after_death = True #

    Whether someone gets an honour - and the honour they get - is decided by an honours committee. The committee’s recommendations go to the Prime Minister and then to the Queen, who awards the honour.

    honours_decided_by_committee = True recommendations_go_to_Prime_Minister = True Queen_awards_honour = True #

    Recommend someone for a gallantry award

    #

    Civilian gallantry awards recognise the bravery of people who’ve put themselves in danger to save (or attempt to save) someone’s life. Recommendations are judged on:

    #
  • degree of risk
    • degree_of_risk = True #
  • how aware the nominee was of the danger
    • awareness_of_danger = True #
  • persistence
    • persistence = True #

    The incident must have taken place in the last 5 years. You can recommend someone after they’ve died – they’ll get a posthumous award. They do not have to be British (except for the George Cross award).

    incident_within_last_5_years = True recommendation_possible_after_death = True non_British_possible_except_for_George_Cross = True

  • search for missing people

    • report_and_deal_with_pollution_and_hazards = True #

#

Overview

#

Special educational needs and disabilities (SEND) can affect a child or young person’s ability to learn. They can affect their:

if special_educational_needs_and_disabilities: #
  • behaviour or ability to socialise, for example they struggle to make friends
    • affects_behaviour_or_socialisation = True #
  • reading and writing, for example because they have dyslexia
    • affects_reading_and_writing = True #
  • ability to understand things
    • affects_ability_to_understand = True #
  • concentration levels, for example because they have ADHD
    • affects_concentration_levels = True #
  • physical ability
    • affects_physical_ability = True #

    Who to talk to

    #

    If you think your child may have special educational needs, contact the SEN co-ordinator, or ‘SENCO’ in your child’s school or nursery.

    if child_in_school_or_nursery: contact_SENCO = True #

    Contact your local council if your child is not in a school or nursery.

    if child_not_in_school_or_nursery: contact_local_council = True #

    Your local Information, Advice and Support (IAS) Service can give you advice about SEND.

    IAS_service_can_provide_advice = True #

    Support your child can receive

    #

    Your child may be eligible for:

    #
  • SEN support - support given in school, like speech therapy
    • SEN_support_possible = True #
  • an education, health and care (EHC) plan - a plan of care for children and young people aged up to 25 who have more complex needs
    • EHC_plan_possible = True #

    If you or your child got support before September 2014 this will continue until your local council changes it to an EHC plan.

    if support_before_september_2014: support_continues_until_EHC_plan = True #

    Children between 5 and 15

    #

    if child_between_5_and_15: #
  • a special learning programme
    • special_learning_programme_needed = True #
  • extra help from a teacher or assistant
    • extra_help_needed = True #
  • to work in a smaller group
    • smaller_group_work_needed = True #
  • observation in class or at break
    • observation_needed = True #
  • help taking part in class activities
    • help_participating_in_class_activities_needed = True #
  • extra encouragement in their learning, for example to ask questions or to try something they find difficult
    • extra_encouragement_needed = True #
  • help communicating with other children
    • help_with_communication_needed = True #
  • support with physical or personal care difficulties, for example eating, getting around school safely or using the toilet
    • support_with_physical_or_personal_care_difficulties_needed = True

Overview

#

You can claim back 25p every time an individual donates £1 to your charity or community amateur sports club (CASC). This is called Gift Aid.

You must be recognised as a charity or CASC for tax purposes.

recognised_as_charity_or_CASC = True #

There are rules on which donations you can claim Gift Aid on.

rules_on_donations_for_gift_aid = True #

You can claim Gift Aid online - you should get your payment within 5 weeks.

claim_gift_aid_online = True payment_within_5_weeks = True #

What the donor needs to do

#

#

    What you can claim it on

    • #
  • make a Gift Aid declaration that gives you permission to claim it
    • claim_gift_aid_on_donations_from_individuals = True #

    You must be recognised as a charity or community amateur sports club (CASC) to claim Gift Aid.

    recognised_as_charity_or_CASC_to_claim_gift_aid = True

#

    • #

    • if considering_taking_off_register or considering_removing_trainee_licence or considering_refusing_extension: ADI_can_be_suspended = True #

    if ADI_suspended: cannot_get_paid_for_driving_lessons = True #

    Claiming compensation

    You can claim compensation if you’ve been suspended but are not then taken off the register.

    claim_compensation_if_suspended_not_taken_off_register = True #

    There are different rules for your ADI registration in Northern Ireland.

    different_rules_in_Northern_Ireland = True #

    Compensation if you stay on the register

    #

    income_losses_possible = True #

    • #

#

Overview

#

A Postgraduate Master’s Loan can help with course fees and living costs while you study a postgraduate master’s course.

postgraduate_masters_loan_available = True #

Funding for postgraduate loans is different if:

#
  • you normally live in Scotland
    • if normally_live_in_scotland: postgraduate_loan_funding_different_in_scotland = True #
  • you normally live in Wales
    • if normally_live_in_wales: postgraduate_loan_funding_different_in_wales = True #
  • you normally live in Northern Ireland.
    • if normally_live_in_northern_ireland: postgraduate_loan_funding_different_in_northern_ireland = True #

    Moving somewhere to study does not count as normally living there.

    moving_to_study_not_counted_as_normally_living_there = True #

    You can also get extra support if you have a disability.

    extra_support_for_disability_available = True #

    You will not be eligible for an Adult Dependants’ Grant, a Childcare Grant or Parents’ Learning Allowance from Student Finance England if you’re studying a master’s course.

    not_eligible_for_grants_from_Student_Finance_England = True #

    What you'll get

    #

    You can get up to:

    #
  • £11,570 if your course starts on or after 1 August 2021
    • #
  • £11,222 if your course started between 1 August 2020 and 31 July 2021
    • #
  • £10,906 if your course started between 1 August 2019 and 31 July 2020
    • if course_starts_on_or_after_1_august_2021: loan_amount = £11,570 elif course_started_between_1_august_2020_and_31_july_2021: loan_amount = £11,222 elif course_started_between_1_august_2019_and_31_july_2020: loan_amount = £10,906 #

    The amount you’ll get is not based on your income or your family’s.

    loan_amount_not_based_on_income = True #

    The Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) may take account of the loan when working out any benefits you receive.

    DWP_may_take_loan_into_account_for_benefit_calculations = True #

    The loan is paid directly to you. You can use it for your course fees and living costs.

#

Overview

#

Redundancy is when you dismiss an employee because you no longer need anyone to do their job. This might be because your business is:

if business_changing or doing_things_differently or changing_location_or_closing_down: redundancy_possible = True #

If you’ve been impacted by coronavirus (COVID-19), you can get funding to continue to pay your employees instead of making them redundant. This is known as furloughing.

if impacted_by_COVID_19: funding_available_for_employee_payment = True furloughing_possible = True #

For a redundancy to be genuine, you must demonstrate that the employee’s job will no longer exist.

genuine_redundancy_requires_job_no_longer_exist = True #

Redundancies can be compulsory or non-compulsory. If you do have to make redundancies you can get help from Jobcentre Plus.

if redundancies_required: redundancies_compulsory = True help_available_from_Jobcentre_Plus = True #

Redundancy pay

#

Employees you make redundant might be entitled to redundancy pay - this is called a ‘statutory redundancy payment’.

redundant_employees_entitled_to_redundancy_pay = True #

To be eligible, an individual must:

#
  • be an employee working under a contract of employment
    • #
  • have at least 2 years’ continuous service
    • #
  • have been dismissed, laid off or put on short-time working - those who opted for early retirement do not qualify
    • if employee_eligible_for_redundancy_pay: eligible_for_redundancy_pay = True #

    You must make the payment when you dismiss the employee, or soon after.

    payment_must_be_made_when_dismissing_employee = True #

    A redundant employee also has the right to a written statement setting out the amount of redundancy payment and how you worked it out.

    redundant_employee_right_to_written_statement = True

Overview

#

#
  • following safety standards and codes of practice
    • follow_safety_standards_and_codes_of_practice = True #
  • ensuring the safety of machinery and equipment
    • ensure_safety_of_machinery_and_equipment = True #

    Fire prevention

    #

    The Maritime and Coastguard Agency (MCA) provides information on requirements for fire protection, fire detection and fire extinction on board ships.

    mca_provides_information_on_fire_prevention = True #

    The rules depend on the size of the ship.

    fire_prevention_rules_depend_on_ship_size = True #

    Requirements for large ships are in the Merchant Shipping (Fire Protection: Large Ships) Regulations 1998.

    requirements_for_large_ships_in_regulations_1998 = True #

    Requirements for small ships are in the Merchant Shipping (Fire Protection: Small Ships) Regulations 1998.

    requirements_for_small_ships_in_regulations_1998 = True #

    You should also read the Merchant Shipping (Fire Protection) Regulations 2003 – it includes amendments to the regulations for large and small ships.

    Contact the MCA to find out more about fire prevention and detection at sea.

    contact_mca_for_fire_prevention_information = True

Your rights

#

As an employee you’re allowed time off to deal with an emergency involving a dependant.

allowed_time_off_for_emergency_involving_dependant = True #

A dependant could be a spouse, partner, child, grandchild, parent, or someone who depends on you for care.

dependant_types = ['spouse', 'partner', 'child', 'grandchild', 'parent', 'someone who depends on you for care'] #

How much you get

#

You’re allowed a reasonable amount of time off to deal with the emergency, but there’s no set amount of time as it depends on the situation.

#

#

#

Overview

#

All employees have an employment contract with their employer. A contract is an agreement that sets out an employee’s:

employment_conditions = True rights = True responsibilities = True duties = True #

These are called the ‘terms’ of the contract.

terms_of_contract = True #

Employees and employers must stick to a contract until it ends (for example, by an employer or employee giving notice or an employee being dismissed) or until the terms are changed (usually by agreement between the employee and employer).

contract_valid_until_end_or_terms_changed = True #

If a person has an agreement to do some work for someone (like paint their house), this isn’t an employment contract but a ‘contract to provide services’.

if agreement_to_do_work: contract_to_provide_services = True #

Accepting a contract

#

As soon as someone accepts a job offer they have a contract with their employer. An employment contract does not have to be written down.

job_offer_accepted = True #

Contract terms

#

The legal parts of a contract are known as ‘terms’. An employer should make clear which parts of a contract are legally binding.

legal_parts_of_contract = True #

Contract terms could be:

#
  • in a written contract, or similar document like a written statement of employment
    • written_contract = True #
  • verbally agreed
    • verbally_agreed_contract = True #
  • in an employee handbook or on a company notice board
    • in_employee_handbook_or_notice_board = True #
  • in an offer letter from the employer
    • in_offer_letter = True #
  • required by law (for example, an employer must pay employees at least the National Minimum Wage)
    • required_by_law = True #
  • in collective agreements - negotiated agreements between employers and trade unions or staff associations
    • collective_agreements = True #
  • implied terms - automatically part of a contract even if they’re not written down
    • implied_terms = True

#

Overview

#

You must pay the tax and Class 1B National Insurance due from your PAYE Settlement Agreement (PSA) by 22 October following the tax year it applies to.

pay_due_by_22_october = True #

This guide is also available in Welsh (Cymraeg)

guide_available_in_welsh = True #

What to include

#

Make your cheque payable to ‘HM Revenue and Customs only’.

cheque_payable_to_HMRC = True #

Write your PAYE Settlement Agreement (PSA) reference number on the back of the cheque. It starts with an ‘X’ and you’ll find it on your payslip.

write_PSA_reference_number_on_cheque = True #

Include the payslip HMRC sent you. Do not fold the payslip or cheque or fasten them together.

include_payslip = True do_not_fold_or_fasten_payslip_or_cheque = True #

Your payment may be delayed if you do not fill in your cheque properly.

if cheque_not_filled_properly: payment_delay_possible = True #

If you want a receipt, include a note asking for one.

include_note_for_receipt = True #

Check your payment has been received

#

You can check your bank or building society statement to confirm the payment has left your account.

check_bank_statement_for_payment_confirmation = True #

If you’re paying by post, you can include a letter with your payment to request a receipt from HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC).

if paying_by_post: include_letter_to_request_receipt_from_HMRC = True

inter_results.doc_code:
#

Overview

#

All employees have an employment contract with their employer. A contract is an agreement that sets out an employee’s:

employment_contract_exists = True #
  • employment conditions
    • employment_conditions = True #
  • rights
    • employee_rights = True #
  • responsibilities
    • employee_responsibilities = True #
  • duties
    • employee_duties = True #

    These are called the ‘terms’ of the contract.

    terms_of_contract = True #

    Employees and employers must stick to a contract until it ends (for example, by an employer or employee giving notice or an employee being dismissed) or until the terms are changed (usually by agreement between the employee and employer).

    contract_must_be_stuck_to_until_end_or_terms_changed = True #

    If a person has an agreement to do some work for someone (like paint their house), this isn’t an employment contract but a ‘contract to provide services’.

    if agreement_to_do_work: employment_contract = False contract_to_provide_services = True #

    Compensation

    #

    If an employee or worker wins a case about another issue (for example, unauthorised deductions from their wage slip), the tribunal may award compensation if there’s been a problem with their written statement as well.

    if employee_or_worker_wins_case: compensation_possible = True if problem_with_written_statement: compensation_awarded = True #

    Compensation can be up to 4 weeks’ pay although there’s a limit on how much a tribunal will award for a week’s pay.

    compensation_up_to_4_weeks_pay = True limit_on_weekly_compensation_award = True

# Answer: up to 4 weeks’ pay

#

Overview

#

All employees have an employment contract with their employer. A contract is an agreement that sets out an employee’s:

employment_conditions = True rights = True responsibilities = True duties = True #

These are called the ‘terms’ of the contract.

terms_of_contract = True #

Employees and employers must stick to a contract until it ends (for example, by an employer or employee giving notice or an employee being dismissed) or until the terms are changed (usually by agreement between the employee and employer).

contract_valid_until_end_or_terms_changed = True #

If a person has an agreement to do some work for someone (like paint their house), this isn’t an employment contract but a ‘contract to provide services’.

if agreement_to_do_work: employment_contract = False contract_to_provide_services = True #

Contract terms

#

The legal parts of a contract are known as ‘terms’. An employer should make clear which parts of a contract are legally binding.

Contract terms could be:

#
  • in a written contract, or similar document like a written statement of employment
    • written_contract_terms = True #
  • verbally agreed

  • in an employee handbook or on a company notice board
    • employee_handbook_terms = True #
  • in an offer letter from the employer
    • offer_letter_terms = True #
  • required by law (for example, an employer must pay employees at least the National Minimum Wage)
    • required_by_law_terms = True #
  • in collective agreements - negotiated agreements between employers and trade unions or staff associations
    • collective_agreements_terms = True #
  • implied terms - automatically part of a contract even if they’re not written down
    • implied_terms = True

#

Overview

#

Redundancy is when you dismiss an employee because you no longer need anyone to do their job. This might be because your business is:

if business_changing or doing_things_differently or changing_location_or_closing_down: redundancy_possible = True #

If you’ve been impacted by coronavirus (COVID-19), you can get funding to continue to pay your employees instead of making them redundant. This is known as furloughing.

if impacted_by_COVID_19: funding_available_for_employee_payment = True furloughing_possible = True #

For a redundancy to be genuine, you must demonstrate that the employee’s job will no longer exist.

genuine_redundancy_requires_job_no_longer_exist = True #

Redundancies can be compulsory or non-compulsory. If you do have to make redundancies you can get help from Jobcentre Plus.

if redundancies_compulsory: help_available_from_Jobcentre_Plus = True #

Giving staff notice

#

You must give staff notice and agree a leaving date once you’ve finished the redundancy consultations.

if redundancy_consultations_finished: staff_notice_and_leaving_date_required = True #

Give staff at least the statutory notice period, based on how long they have worked.

# Length of service | Notice you must give # 1 month to 2 years | At least a week # 2 years to 12 years | A week’s notice for every year employed # 12 or more years | 12 weeks if length_of_service >= 1 and length_of_service <= 2: notice_period = "at least a week" elif length_of_service > 2 and length_of_service <= 12: notice_period = "a week’s notice for every year employed" elif length_of_service > 12: notice_period = "12 weeks" #

You can allow staff to leave earlier than the planned leaving date (for example without notice) by offering payment in lieu of notice.

allow_staff_to_leave_earlier_with_payment_in_lieu_of_notice = True
inter_results.full_response:
# <tr>1 month to 2 years | At least a week</tr>
# Answer: at least a week

# Document: #

Overview

#

Redundancy is when you dismiss an employee because you no longer need anyone to do their job. This might be because your business is:

if business_changing or doing_things_differently or changing_location_or_closing_down: redundancy_possible = True #

If you’ve been impacted by coronavirus (COVID-19), you can get funding to continue to pay your employees instead of making them redundant. This is known as furloughing.

if impacted_by_coronavirus: funding_available_for_employee_payment_instead_of_redundancy = True furloughing_possible = True #

For a redundancy to be genuine, you must demonstrate that the employee’s job will no longer exist.

redundancy_genuine_if_job_no_longer_exists = True #

Redundancies can be compulsory or non-compulsory. If you do have to make redundancies you can get help from Jobcentre Plus.

if redundancies_made: help_available_from_Jobcentre_Plus = True #

Statutory redundancy pay rates

#

These are based on an employee’s age and length of employment and are counted back from the date of dismissal.

#

Employees get:

#
  • 1.5 weeks’ pay for each full year of employment after their 41st birthday
    • #
  • a week’s pay for each full year of employment after their 22nd birthday
    • #
  • half a week’s pay for each full year of employment up to their 22nd birthday
    • #

    Length of service is capped at 20 years.

    #

    Your employee’s weekly pay is the average they earned per week over the 12 weeks before the day they got their redundancy notice.

    #

    If your employee earned less than usual because you used the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme to put them ‘on furlough’, you must work out their redundancy payments based on what they would have earned normally.

    #

    Weekly pay is capped at £544. The maximum amount of statutory redundancy pay is £16,320.

    #

    Statutory redundancy pay rates may be different in Northern Ireland.

    #

    You can give your staff extra redundancy pay if you want to, or have a qualifying period of less than 2 years.

    #

    You can use the redundancy pay calculator to work out payments.

    if redundancy_pay_rates: #
  • 1.5 weeks’ pay for each full year of employment after their 41st birthday
    • redundancy_pay_rate_after_41 = 1.5 #
  • a week’s pay for each full year of employment after their 22nd birthday
    • redundancy_pay_rate_after_22 = 1 #
  • half a week’s pay for each full year of employment up to their 22nd birthday
    • redundancy_pay_rate_up_to_22 = 0.5 #

    Length of service is capped at 20 years.

    length_of_service_capped_at_20_years = True #

    Your employee’s weekly pay is the average they earned per week over the 12 weeks before the day they got their redundancy notice.

    employee_weekly_pay_based_on_12_week_average = True #

    If your employee earned less than usual because you used the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme to put them ‘on furlough’, you must work out their redundancy payments based on what they would have earned normally.

    if employee_earned_less_due_to_furlough: calculate_redundancy_payments_based_on_normal_earnings = True #

    Weekly pay is capped at £544. The maximum amount of statutory redundancy pay is £16,320.

    weekly_pay_capped_at_544 = True maximum_redundancy_pay = 16320 #

    Statutory redundancy pay rates may be different in Northern Ireland.

    statutory_redundancy_pay_rates_different_in_northern_ireland = True #

    You can give your staff extra redundancy pay if you want to, or have a qualifying period of less than 2 years.

    extra_redundancy_pay_possible = True qualifying_period_less_than_2_years = True #

    You can use the redundancy pay calculator to work out payments.

    redundancy_pay_calculator_available = True

#

Your rights

#

As an employee you’re allowed time off to deal with an emergency involving a dependant.

allowed_time_off_for_emergency_involving_dependant = True #

A dependant could be a spouse, partner, child, grandchild, parent, or someone who depends on you for care.

dependant_types = ['spouse', 'partner', 'child', 'grandchild', 'parent', 'someone who depends on you for care'] #

How much you get

#

You’re allowed a reasonable amount of time off to deal with the emergency, but there’s no set amount of time as it depends on the situation.

reasonable_amount_of_time_off_allowed = True #

Tell your employer as soon as possible how much time you’ll need so it can be agreed.

tell_employer_as_soon_as_possible = True #

What's an emergency?

#

You could get time off when a dependant is involved in the following emergencies.

#

Illness, injury or assault

#

This includes mental or physical illnesses that don’t have to be life-threatening or need full-time care - it could be an existing condition that has worsened.

illness_injury_or_assault_emergency = True #

For example, if a dependant is mugged without being physically hurt, you could take time off to comfort or help them.

example_emergency_situation_1 = "dependant is mugged without being physically hurt" #

You can also take time off to arrange longer term care for a dependant.

example_emergency_situation_2 = "arrange longer term care for a dependant"

    #

    Risk assessments must be reviewed every year and whenever there are significant changes to either the ship or working activities.

    Read chapter 1 of the ‘Code of safe working practices for merchant seafarers 2018’ for the basic requirements for risk assessments on board ships.

#

Overview

#

You must pay the tax and Class 1B National Insurance due from your PAYE Settlement Agreement (PSA) by 22 October following the tax year it applies to.

pay_due_tax_and_NI_by_22_October = True #

This guide is also available in Welsh (Cymraeg)

guide_available_in_welsh = True #

Up to 2 days

#
  • online or telephone banking (Faster Payments)
    • #
  • CHAPS
    • #
  • by debit or corporate credit card online
    • #
  • at your bank or building society

    By debit or corporate credit card online

    You can pay online.

    pay_online_possible = True #

    There’s a fee if you pay by corporate credit card or corporate debit card. The fee is not refundable.

    fee_for_corporate_credit_or_debit_card_payment = True #

    There’s no fee if you pay by personal debit card.

    no_fee_for_personal_debit_card_payment = True #

    You cannot pay by personal credit card.

    personal_credit_card_payment_not_possible = True #

    You’ll need your PAYE Settlement Agreement (PSA) reference number. It starts with an X and is on the payslip HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) sent you.

    PSA_reference_number_required = True #

    If you do not have your PSA number, contact the HMRC office that’s dealing with your application.

    contact_HMRC_if_no_PSA_number = True #

    Do not use your PAYE Accounts Office reference number. Your payment may be delayed if you use the wrong reference.

    do_not_use_PAYE_Accounts_Office_reference_number = True #

    HMRC will accept your payment on the date you make it (even on bank holidays and weekends) - not the date it reaches HMRC’s account.

    payment_accepted_on_date_made = True #

    If you’re unable to pay your PSA in full by card, you should use another payment method like a bank transfer.

    if unable_to_pay_in_full_by_card: use_another_payment_method = True

# Question: I own and operate an electronics company in Southern England, which currently has 140 employees. As part of our expansion into the EU, about 5 of our employees will need to be seconded to our office in France for a 6 month period. Their current principal statements make no mention of overseas employment.. If I make changes to their principal statements, how soon do I need to notify the affected workers?
company_location = "Southern England"
employee_count = 140
expansion_into_eu = True
employees_seconded_to_france = 5
secondment_duration = 6
principal_statements_no_overseas_employment = True
changes_to_principal_statements = True
notification_period = None # This is the variable that answers the question
inter_results.doc_code:
#

Overview

#

All employees have an employment contract with their employer. A contract is an agreement that sets out an employee’s:

employment_contract_exists = True #
  • employment conditions
    • employment_conditions = True #
  • rights
    • employee_rights = True #
  • responsibilities
    • employee_responsibilities = True #
  • duties
    • employee_duties = True #

    These are called the ‘terms’ of the contract.

    terms_of_contract = True #

    Employees and employers must stick to a contract until it ends (for example, by an employer or employee giving notice or an employee being dismissed) or until the terms are changed (usually by agreement between the employee and employer).

    contract_must_be_stuck_to_until_end_or_terms_changed = True #

    If a person has an agreement to do some work for someone (like paint their house), this isn’t an employment contract but a ‘contract to provide services’.

    if agreement_to_do_work_for_someone: contract_is_contract_to_provide_services = True #

    Written statement of employment particulars

    #

    An employer must give employees and workers a document stating the main conditions of employment when they start work. This is known as a ‘written statement of employment particulars’. It is not an employment contract.

    written_statement_of_employment_particulars_required = True #

    The written statement is made up of:

    #
  • the main document (known as a ‘principal statement’)
    • #
  • a wider written statement
    • principal_statement_required = True wider_written_statement_required = True #

    The employer must provide the principal statement on the first day of employment and the wider written statement within 2 months of the start of employment.

    principal_statement_provided_on_first_day = True wider_written_statement_provided_within_2_months = True #

    Employers must tell employees or workers about any changes to the written statement. They must do this within one month of making the change.

    changes_to_written_statement_must_be_communicated_within_1_month = True #

    There are special rules for agencies on documents that they need to provide to agency workers.

    special_rules_for_agencies_on_documents = True #

    The principal statement

    #

    The principal statement must include at least:

    #
  • the employer’s name
    • employer_name_required = True #
  • the employee’s or worker’s name, job title or a description of work and start date
    • employee_name_required = True job_title_or_description_required = True start_date_required = True #
  • how much and how often an employee or worker will get paid
    • payment_details_required = True #
  • hours and days of work and if and how they may vary (also if employees or workers will have to work Sundays, nights or overtime)
    • working_hours_details_required = True #
  • holiday entitlement (and if that includes public holidays)
    • holiday_entitlement_details_required = True #
  • where an employee or worker will be working and whether they might have to relocate
    • work_location_details_required = True #
  • if an employee or worker works in different places, where these will be and what the employer’s address is
    • multiple_work_locations_details_required = True employer_address_required = True #
  • how long a job is expected to last (and what the end date is if it’s a fixed-term contract)
    • job_duration_details_required = True #
  • how long any probation period is and what its conditions are
    • probation_period_details_required = True #
  • any other benefits (for example, childcare vouchers and lunch)
    • other_benefits_details_required = True #
  • obligatory training, whether or not this is paid for by the employer
    • obligatory_training_details_required = True #

    For employees, it must also include the date that a previous job started if it counts towards a period of continuous employment.

    if employee: previous_job_start_date_required = True #

    Working abroad

    #

    If an employee or worker has to work outside the UK for more than a month, the principal statement must also include:

    #
  • how long they’ll be abroad
    • working_abroad_duration_required = True #
  • what currency they’ll be paid in
    • currency_for_payment_required = True #
  • what additional pay or benefits they’ll get
    • additional_pay_or_benefits_required = True #
  • terms relating to their return to the UK
    • terms_for_return_to_UK_required = True
inter_results.full_response:
#

Employers must tell employees or workers about any changes to the written statement. They must do this within one month of making the change.

inter_results.doc_code:
#

Overview

#

Redundancy is when you dismiss an employee because you no longer need anyone to do their job. This might be because your business is:

if business_changing or doing_things_differently or changing_location_or_closing_down: redundancy_possible = True #

If you’ve been impacted by coronavirus (COVID-19), you can get funding to continue to pay your employees instead of making them redundant. This is known as furloughing.

if impacted_by_COVID_19: funding_available_for_employee_payment = True furloughing_possible = True #

For a redundancy to be genuine, you must demonstrate that the employee’s job will no longer exist.

genuine_redundancy_requirement = True #

Redundancies can be compulsory or non-compulsory. If you do have to make redundancies you can get help from Jobcentre Plus.

if redundancies_compulsory: help_available_from_Jobcentre_Plus = True #

Redundancy consultations

#

If you do not consult employees in a redundancy situation, any redundancies you make will almost certainly be unfair and you could be taken to an employment tribunal.

if no_employee_consultation: redundancies_may_be_unfair = True may_be_taken_to_employment_tribunal = True #

You must follow ‘collective consultation’ rules if you’re making 20 or more employees redundant within any 90-day period at a single establishment.

if making_20_or_more_redundancies_within_90_days: follow_collective_consultation_rules = True #

There are no set rules to follow if there are fewer than 20 redundancies planned, but it’s good practice to fully consult employees and their representatives. An employment tribunal could decide that you’ve dismissed your staff unfairly if you do not.

if fewer_than_20_redundancies_planned: good_practice_to_fully_consult_employees = True employment_tribunal_may_decide_unfair_dismissal = True #

Consultation does not have to end in agreement, but it must be carried out with a view to reaching it, including ways of avoiding or reducing the redundancies.

consultation_not_require_agreement = True consultation_with_view_to_reaching_agreement = True ways_to_avoid_or_reduce_redundancies_discussed = True

  • a cesspool (also called a cesspit) - a sealed tank that collects the sewage

    • sewage_goes_to_non_standard_system = True #

Overview

#

When you set up your limited company, you automatically get different reporting dates for the first:

#
  • annual accounts you send to Companies House
    • #
  • Company Tax Return you send to HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC)
    • #

    You may also have to send (‘file’) 2 tax returns to cover your first year in business.

    if set_up_limited_company: different_reporting_dates_for_first_year = True #

    Example

    # Action | Date # Company set up and started trading | 11 May 2013 # First accounting period for Corporation Tax ends | 10 May 2014 # Accounting reference date | 31 May 2014 # Second accounting period for Corporation Tax ends | 31 May 2014 #

    Prepare your first set of accounts for 11 May 2013 to 31 May 2014. Then file your:

    #
  • first tax return for 11 May 2013 to 10 May 2014
    • #
  • second tax return for 11 to 31 May 2014
    • #

    After you do this, your accounts and tax returns will normally cover your company’s financial year from 1 June to 31 May.

    if prepare_first_set_of_accounts and file_first_tax_return and file_second_tax_return: accounts_and_tax_returns_cover_financial_year = True #

    Example

    # Action | Date # Company set up | 11 May 2013 # Started trading | 22 July 2013 # Register for Corporation Tax | 26 August 2013 # Accounting reference date | 31 May 2014 #

    Prepare accounts for 11 May 2013 to 31 May 2014. Then file one tax return for your trading period from 22 July 2013 to 31 May 2014.

    #

    After you do this, your dates for accounts and tax returns will normally match your company’s financial year from 1 June to 31 May every year.

    if prepare_accounts and file_tax_return: accounts_and_tax_returns_match_financial_year = True #

    Check the ‘notice to deliver a Company Tax Return’ you get after your first year. If it covers your dormant and trading periods you must file 2 tax returns - one for your trading period and one for your dormant period.

    if notice_to_deliver_tax_return_covers_dormant_and_trading_periods: file_two_tax_returns = True #

    Example:

    # Action | Date # Company set up | 11 May 2013 # Started trading | 22 July 2013 # Accounting reference date | 31 May 2014 #

    Prepare one set of accounts for 11 May 2013 to 31 May 2014. Then file your:

    #
  • first tax return for your dormant period from 11 May to 21 July 2013
    • #
  • second tax return for your trading period from 22 July 2013 to 31 May 2014
    • #

    After you do this, your dates for accounts and tax returns will normally match your company’s financial year from 1 June to 31 May every year.

    if prepare_one_set_of_accounts and file_first_tax_return and file_second_tax_return: accounts_and_tax_returns_match_financial_year = True

#

    if limited_company_set_up: different_reporting_dates_for_first_year = True #

    You started trading the day your company set up

    #

    if started_trading_same_day_as_set_up: file_2_tax_returns = True #

    Example

    # Action | Date # Company set up and started trading | 11 May 2013 # First accounting period for Corporation Tax ends | 10 May 2014 # Accounting reference date | 31 May 2014 # Second accounting period for Corporation Tax ends | 31 May 2014 #

    Prepare your first set of accounts for 11 May 2013 to 31 May 2014. Then file your:

    #
  • first tax return for 11 May 2013 to 10 May 2014
    • #
  • second tax return for 11 to 31 May 2014
    • #

    After you do this, your accounts and tax returns will normally cover your company’s financial year from 1 June to 31 May.

    if first_accounting_period_ends and second_accounting_period_ends: prepare_first_set_of_accounts = True file_first_tax_return = True file_second_tax_return = True accounts_and_tax_returns_cover_financial_year = True #

    Example

    #

    • #
  • equipment and machinery
    • #
  • shares
    • company_assets = ['land and property', 'equipment and machinery', 'shares'] #

    #
  • limited companies
    • #
  • most unincorporated associations, for example clubs and co-operatives
    • #
  • foreign companies with a UK branch or office
    • #

    You pay Capital Gains Tax instead if you’re a self-employed sole trader or business partner.

    if limited_company or unincorporated_association or foreign_company_with_UK_branch: pays_Corporation_Tax_on_chargeable_gains = True else: pays_Capital_Gains_Tax_instead = True #

    #

    #

    You’ll need to use the asset’s market value if your business gave it away, or sold it for less than it was worth to help the buyer.

    #

    You can deduct any costs, for example solicitors’ fees or Stamp Duty.

    chargeable_gain = True difference_between_purchase_price_and_sale_price = True use_market_value_if_given_away_or_sold_below_value = True deduct_costs = True
