#

How it works

#

You could get a Funeral Expenses Payment (also called a Funeral Payment) if you get certain benefits and need help to pay for a funeral you’re arranging.

funeral_expenses_payment_possible = True #

This guide is also available in Welsh (Cymraeg).

guide_available_in_welsh = True #

Eligibility

#

You can get a Funeral Expenses Payment if all of the following apply:

if meet_eligibility_criteria: eligible_for_funeral_expenses_payment = True #
  • you get certain benefits or tax credits
    • get_certain_benefits_or_tax_credits = True #
  • you meet the rules on your relationship with the deceased
    • meet_rules_on_relationship_with_deceased = True #
  • you’re arranging a funeral in the UK, the European Economic Area (EEA) or Switzerland
    • arranging_funeral_in_UK_EEA_Switzerland = True #

    You might be able to get other help to pay for the funeral if you’re not eligible for Funeral Expenses Payment.

    if not eligible_for_funeral_expenses_payment: other_help_possible_to_pay_for_funeral = True #

    Benefits and tax credits you must get

    #

    You (or your partner) must get one or more of the following:

    if get_one_or_more_of_benefits_or_tax_credits: eligible_for_funeral_expenses_payment = True #
  • Income Support
    • income_support = True #
  • income-based Jobseeker’s Allowance
    • jobseekers_allowance = True #
  • income-related Employment and Support Allowance
    • employment_and_support_allowance = True #
  • Pension Credit
    • pension_credit = True #
  • Housing Benefit
    • housing_benefit = True #
  • the disability or severe disability element of Working Tax Credit
    • working_tax_credit_disability_severe_disability_element = True #
  • Child Tax Credit
    • child_tax_credit = True #
  • Universal Credit
    • universal_credit = True #

    You might also be eligible if you’re getting a Support for Mortgage Interest loan.

    if getting_support_for_mortgage_interest_loan: eligible_for_funeral_expenses_payment = True #

    You can still claim Funeral Expenses Payment if you’ve applied for these benefits and you’re waiting to hear about your claim.

    if applied_for_benefits_and_waiting_to_hear: can_still_claim_funeral_expenses_payment = True #

    If you were responsible for a deceased child but you’re not their parent, the non-resident parent must get one or more of these benefits.

    if responsible_for_deceased_child_but_not_parent: non_resident_parent_gets_benefits = True #

    If there’s a close relative of the deceased who is not getting one of these benefits, you might not be able to claim Funeral Expenses Payment.

    if close_relative_not_getting_benefits: may_not_be_able_to_claim_funeral_expenses_payment = True #

    Rules on your relationship with the deceased

    #

    You must be one of the following:

    if meet_rules_on_relationship_with_deceased: eligible_for_funeral_expenses_payment = True #
  • the partner of the deceased when they died
    • partner_of_deceased = True #
  • a close relative or close friend of the deceased
    • close_relative_or_friend_of_deceased = True #
  • the parent of a baby stillborn after 24 weeks of pregnancy
    • parent_of_stillborn_baby = True #
  • the parent or person responsible for a deceased child who was under 16 (or under 20 and in approved education or training)
    • parent_or_person_responsible_for_deceased_child = True #

    You might not get a Funeral Expenses Payment if another close relative of the deceased (such as a sibling or parent) is in work.

    if close_relative_in_work: may_not_get_funeral_expenses_payment = True

#

You could get a Funeral Expenses Payment (also called a Funeral Payment) if you get certain benefits and need help to pay for a funeral you’re arranging.

#

You (or your partner) must get one or more of the following:

#
  • Income Support
    • #
  • income-based Jobseeker’s Allowance
    • #
  • income-related Employment and Support Allowance
    • #
  • Pension Credit
    • #
  • Housing Benefit
    • #
  • the disability or severe disability element of Working Tax Credit
    • #
  • Child Tax Credit
    • #
  • Universal Credit
    • #

    You might also be eligible if you’re getting a Support for Mortgage Interest loan.

    #

    You can still claim Funeral Expenses Payment if you’ve applied for these benefits and you’re waiting to hear about your claim.

    #

    If you were responsible for a deceased child but you’re not their parent, the non-resident parent must get one or more of these benefits.

    #

    If there’s a close relative of the deceased who is not getting one of these benefits, you might not be able to claim Funeral Expenses Payment.

    #

    You must be one of the following:

    #
  • the partner of the deceased when they died
    • #
  • a close relative or close friend of the deceased
    • #
  • the parent of a baby stillborn after 24 weeks of pregnancy
    • #
  • the parent or person responsible for a deceased child who was under 16 (or under 20 and in approved education or training)
    • #

    You might not get a Funeral Expenses Payment if another close relative of the deceased (such as a sibling or parent) is in work.

    # Answer: yes

#
  • Fill in the ‘permanent export’ section of your vehicle log book (V5C) and detach it from the log book.
    • fill_in_permanent_export_section_of_V5C = True detach_permanent_export_section_from_V5C = True #
  • Send the completed ‘permanent export’ section to DVLA, Swansea, SA99 1BD. Include a letter if you’ve moved abroad and want your vehicle tax refund (if you’re entitled to one) sent to your new address.
    • send_completed_permanent_export_section_to_DVLA = True include_letter_for_vehicle_tax_refund = True #
  • Keep the rest of your log book (V5C) - you need it to register your vehicle in the country you’re taking it to.
    • keep_rest_of_V5C = True #
  • Update the address on your driving licence if you’re moving home.
    • if moving_home: update_address_on_driving_licence = True #

    If you’re due a refund, it will take longer than usual because of coronavirus (COVID-19). The refund is worked out from the date DVLA gets your ‘permanent export’ section.

    if buying_vehicle_to_take_abroad: seller_must_follow_correct_process = True seller_must_provide_full_V5C = True

work_not_represented_by_results = True
pandemic_impact_on_results = True
challenge_a_level_results = None # This is the variable that answers the question
inter_results.doc_code:
#

Overview

#

You can challenge the results of an exam or qualification if you think it’s wrong.

can_challenge_exam_or_qualification_results = True #

Request a review

#

You can challenge the result of a GCSE, AS level or A level exam.

#

You can also challenge the result of another qualification.

can_challenge_GCSE_AS_A_level_exam = True can_challenge_other_qualification = True #

Who can request a GCSE, AS level or A level review

#

You can ask your school or college to get an exam result looked at again (known as ‘requesting a review’). You cannot request a review yourself unless you’re a private candidate, for example you were home schooled.

if private_candidate: can_request_review = True #

What happens next

#

The mark will be changed if the reviewer thinks it’s wrong. The new mark may be higher or lower than the original.

mark_change_possible = True #

You can ask your school or college’s exams officer for more information about their internal appeals procedure and their policy on reviews of marking and moderation.

ask_exams_officer_for_appeals_procedure = True #

You can appeal against a review if you’re unhappy with the decision.

can_appeal_against_review = True #

You or your school may have to pay if the mark is not changed.

if mark_not_changed: payment_required = True

#

You can challenge the result of a GCSE, AS level or A level exam.

#

You can ask your school or college to get an exam result looked at again (known as ‘requesting a review’). You cannot request a review yourself unless you’re a private candidate, for example you were home schooled.

information_on_voters = True
signed_up_to_open_register = False
opt_out_of_open_register = None # This is the variable that answers the question
inter_results.doc_code:
#

Get on the electoral register

#

The electoral register (sometimes called the ‘electoral roll’) lists the names and addresses of everyone who’s registered to vote.

electoral_register_lists_names_and_addresses = True #

Use the register to vote service to:

#
  • get on the electoral register
    • get_on_electoral_register = True #
  • update your details (for example change your name or address)
    • update_details = True #

    To check whether you’re already on the register, contact:

    #
  • your local Electoral Registration Office if you live in England, Scotland or Wales
    • if live_in_england_scotland_wales: contact_local_Electoral_Registration_Office = True #
  • the Electoral Office for Northern Ireland (EONI) if you live in Northern Ireland
    • if live_in_northern_ireland: contact_Electoral_Office_for_Northern_Ireland = True #

    Opt out of the 'open register'

    #

    There are 2 versions of the electoral register - the full version and the ‘open register’ (known as the ‘edited register’ in Northern Ireland).

    two_versions_of_electoral_register = True #

    If you registered to vote anonymously your details will not appear on either version of the electoral register. You will still be able to vote.

    if registered_to_vote_anonymously: details_not_appear_on_either_version_of_register = True still_able_to_vote = True #

    How to opt out of the open register

    #

    You can opt out of the open register. This is the version of the register that’s available to anyone who wants to buy a copy.

    opt_out_of_open_register = True #

    To opt out, either:

    #
  • use the register to vote service (even if you’re already registered)
    • if use_register_to_vote_service: opt_out_of_open_register = True #
  • contact your local Electoral Registration Office if you live in England, Scotland or Wales
    • if live_in_england_scotland_wales: contact_local_Electoral_Registration_Office = True #
  • contact the Electoral Office for Northern Ireland (EONI) if you live in Northern Ireland
    • if live_in_northern_ireland: contact_Electoral_Office_for_Northern_Ireland = True #

    Opting out does not affect your right to vote.

    opting_out_does_not_affect_right_to_vote = True #

    When you opt out of the open register, your details will still appear on the full version of the electoral register.

    details_appear_on_full_version_of_register_when_opt_out = True
inter_results.full_response:

    • #

    When you opt out of the open register, your details will still appear on the full version of the electoral register.

#

Overview

#

If your sports club is eligible, you can become a community amateur sports club (CASC). You’ll get:

  • tax relief on income, gains and profits from some activities

  • business rates relief
    • business_rates_relief = True #

    To benefit you must register with HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC).

    register_with_HMRC = True #

    You can claim relief on money you use to promote and provide facilities for eligible sports. These are known as ‘qualifying purposes’.

    claim_relief_on_money_for_qualifying_purposes = True #

    You can’t remove a CASC from the register (‘deregistration’) though you can close it if the club’s members vote and agree.

    CASC_cannot_be_deregistered = True CASC_can_be_closed_with_member_vote = True #

    Eligibility

    #

    To register as a CASC you must provide facilities for eligible sports and encourage people to take part. Under the new rules from 1 April 2015, at least 50% of members must take part.

    if provide_facilities_and_encourage_participation and at_least_50_percent_members_participate: eligible_for_CASC_registration = True #

    You must also:

    #
  • be set up with a formal constitution, known as a governing document
    • set_up_with_governing_document = True #
  • be open to the whole community and have affordable membership fees
    • open_to_whole_community_and_affordable_membership_fees = True #
  • be organised on an amateur basis
    • organised_on_amateur_basis = True #
  • be set up and provide facilities in the UK, the EU, Iceland, Liechtenstein or Norway (but in one country only)
    • set_up_and_provide_facilities_in_eligible_countries = True #
  • be managed by ‘fit and proper persons’
    • managed_by_fit_and_proper_persons = True #

    CASC_open_to_whole_community = True #

#

#

Eligibility

#

#
  • meet the residency requirements (your college will check this)

There’s a different process if you want to complain about your solicitor’s behaviour.

complaint_process_for_solicitor_behaviour = True #

#

download_and_fill_in_N208_form = True copies_required = 3 application_fee = £45 #

Send a cheque made payable to ‘HMCTS’ with all 3 copies of your completed form and a copy of your solicitor’s bill to:

apply_to_local_District_Registry_if_outside_London = True #

Apply to your nearest county court if the original case was dealt with by a county court and your solicitor’s bill is for £5,000 or less.

apply_to_nearest_county_court_if_original_case_dealt_with_by_county_court_and_bill_5000_or_less = True

if in_UK: should_apply_for_passport_urgently = True #

What an emergency travel document lets you do

#

You can use an emergency travel document to travel to your destination through a maximum of 5 countries. You can also normally use it to return to the country you’re applying from if you live there.

emergency_travel_document_allows_travel_to_max_5_countries = True emergency_travel_document_allows_return_to_country_of_application = True #

visa_may_be_required_for_leaving_country_or_traveling_through_other_countries = True check_with_embassy_or_consulate_for_each_country = True #

If your final destination is the UK, border staff will keep your emergency travel document when you arrive. Border staff at a different final destination might also keep the document.

if final_destination_is_UK: emergency_travel_document_kept_by_border_staff_upon_arrival = True if different_final_destination: emergency_travel_document_might_be_kept_by_border_staff = True

# Answer: maximum of 5 countries

How it works

#

You get Child Benefit if you’re responsible for bringing up a child who is:

#
  • under 16
    • #
  • under 20 if they stay in approved education or training
    • if responsible_for_bringing_up_child: get_child_benefit = True child_under_16 = True child_under_20_in_approved_education_or_training = True #

    Only one person can get Child Benefit for a child.

    only_one_person_get_child_benefit = True #

    It’s paid every 4 weeks and there’s no limit to how many children you can claim for.

    child_benefit_paid_every_4_weeks = True no_limit_on_number_of_children_claimed_for = True #

    This guide is also available in Welsh (Cymraeg).

    guide_available_in_welsh = True #

    By claiming Child Benefit:

    #
  • you can get National Insurance credits which count towards your State Pension
    • get_national_insurance_credits = True #
  • your child will automatically get a National Insurance number when they’re 16 years old
    • child_gets_national_insurance_number_at_16 = True #

    If you choose not to get Child Benefit payments, you should still fill in and send off the claim form.

    if choose_not_to_get_child_benefit_payments: still_fill_and_send_claim_form = True #

    If you or your partner earn over £50,000

    #

    You may have to pay back some of your Child Benefit in tax if your (or your partner’s) individual income is over £50,000.

    if individual_income_over_50000: may_have_to_pay_back_child_benefit_in_tax = True #

    If you or your partner earn over £50,000

#

How it works

#

You can apply for an emergency travel document (sometimes called an ‘emergency passport’) if you’re abroad, need to travel and cannot get a passport in time.

if abroad and need_to_travel and cannot_get_passport_in_time: can_apply_for_emergency_travel_document = True #

If you’re in the UK you should apply for a passport urgently.

if in_UK: should_apply_for_passport_urgently = True #

What an emergency travel document lets you do

#

You can use an emergency travel document to travel to your destination through a maximum of 5 countries. You can also normally use it to return to the country you’re applying from if you live there.

emergency_travel_document_allows_travel_to_destination_through_max_5_countries = True emergency_travel_document_allows_return_to_country_of_application = True #

Your travel plans (countries and dates) will be printed on your emergency travel document. If you change your travel plans once you have your emergency travel document, you’ll need to apply for a new one.

travel_plans_printed_on_emergency_travel_document = True if change_travel_plans_after_getting_emergency_travel_document: need_to_apply_for_new_one = True #

You may need a visa to leave the country you’re in or to travel through other countries with your emergency travel document. Check with the embassy or consulate of each country.

visa_may_be_required_to_leave_country_or_travel_through_other_countries = True #

If your final destination is the UK, border staff will keep your emergency travel document when you arrive. Border staff at a different final destination might also keep the document.

if final_destination_is_UK: emergency_travel_document_kept_by_border_staff = True else: emergency_travel_document_may_be_kept_by_border_staff = True #

How to apply

#

You can apply online.

apply_online = True #

It costs £100 to apply for an emergency travel document. The fee is not refundable. You can pay online as part of your application. If you do not, you’ll be asked to pay over the phone.

emergency_travel_document_application_fee = 100 fee_not_refundable = True pay_online_as_part_of_application = True if not pay_online_as_part_of_application: asked_to_pay_over_phone = True #

You might need to attend an appointment at your nearest British embassy, high commission or consulate after you apply online. You’ll be told after you’ve submitted your application whether you need an appointment.

if need_appointment_after_online_application: appointment_at_nearest_British_embassy_required = True #

You’ll need to give a contact telephone number and email address as part of your application.

contact_telephone_number_required = True contact_email_address_required = True #

Apply now

. (This is not modeled in code as it is a call-to-action statement)

Overview

What you can claim for

#

    only_one_person_get_child_benefit = True #

    child_benefit_paid_every_4_weeks = True no_limit_on_number_of_children_claimed_for = True #

    This guide is also available in Welsh (Cymraeg).

    guide_available_in_welsh = True #

    #

    • get_national_insurance_credits = True #

    • child_gets_national_insurance_number_at_16 = True #

    If you choose not to get Child Benefit payments, you should still fill in and send off the claim form.

    if choose_not_to_get_child_benefit_payments: still_fill_and_send_claim_form = True #

    If you or your partner earn over £50,000

    if individual_income_over_50000: may_have_to_pay_back_child_benefit_in_tax = True #

    If you or your partner earn over £50,000

    #

    You can get Child Benefit if your (or your partner’s) individual income is over £50,000, but you may be taxed on the benefit. This is known as the High Income Child Benefit Tax Charge.

    if individual_income_over_50000: get_child_benefit = True may_be_taxed_on_benefit = True high_income_child_benefit_tax_charge = True #

    If your partner’s income is also over £50,000 but yours is higher, you’re responsible for paying the tax charge. You need to fill in a Self Assessment tax return each tax year and pay what you owe.

    if partner_income_over_50000 and your_income_higher: responsible_for_paying_tax_charge = True fill_in_self_assessment_tax_return = True #

    Use the Child Benefit tax calculator to estimate how much tax you may have to pay.

    Once you earn £60,000 you lose all of your benefit through tax.

inter_results.doc_code:
#

Overview

#

Anything posted or couriered to you from another country goes through customs to check it is not banned or restricted and you pay the right tax and ‘duty’ on it.

posted_or_couriered_from_another_country = True #

This includes anything new or used that you:

if new_or_used: eligible_for_customs_check = True #
  • buy online
    • buy_online = True #
  • buy abroad and send back to the UK
    • buy_abroad_and_send_to_UK = True #
  • receive as a gift
    • receive_as_gift = True #

    Your responsibilities

    #

    Before receiving your goods, you may have to pay VAT, Customs Duty or Excise Duty if they were sent to:

    #
  • Great Britain (England, Wales and Scotland) from outside the UK
    • #
  • Northern Ireland from countries outside the UK and the European Union (EU)
    • if sent_to_Great_Britain_from_outside_UK or sent_to_Northern_Ireland_from_outside_UK_and_EU: may_have_to_pay_VAT_Customs_Duty_Excise_Duty = True #

    You must also check that the sender:

    #
  • pays Excise Duty on any alcohol or tobacco sent from the EU to Northern Ireland
    • #
  • declares goods correctly if they’re sent from outside the UK (or from outside the EU for Northern Ireland)
    • if sender_pays_Excise_Duty_for_alcohol_or_tobacco_to_Northern_Ireland_from_EU or sender_declares_goods_correctly_from_outside_UK: must_check_sender_responsibilities = True #

    Your goods may be seized if you do not follow the rules. You may also be fined or prosecuted.

    if not_follow_rules: goods_may_be_seized = True may_be_fined_or_prosecuted = True #

    Tax and duty

    #

    You’ll be contacted by Royal Mail, Parcelforce or the courier company if you need to pay any VAT, duty or delivery charges (‘handling fees’) to receive your goods.

    contacted_by_delivery_company_for_payment = True #

    They’ll send you a bill stating exactly which fees you need to pay.

    bill_sent_by_delivery_company = True #

    They’ll normally hold your parcel for about 3 weeks. If you have not paid the bill by then, your parcel will be returned to the sender.

    parcel_held_for_3_weeks = True parcel_returned_if_bill_not_paid = True #

    You will not have to pay anything to the delivery company to receive goods worth less than £135 unless they’re gifts over £39 or excise goods (for example, alcohol and tobacco).

    if goods_worth_less_than_135: no_payment_to_delivery_company_required = True # unless they’re gifts over £39 or excise goods (for example, alcohol and tobacco) if gifts_over_39_or_excise_goods: payment_to_delivery_company_required = True #

    VAT

    #

    VAT is charged on all goods (except for gifts worth £39 or less) sent from:

    #
  • outside the UK to Great Britain
    • #
  • outside the UK and the EU to Northern Ireland
    • if sent_to_Great_Britain_from_outside_UK or sent_to_Northern_Ireland_from_outside_UK_and_EU: VAT_charged = True #

    VAT is not charged on goods that are gifts worth £39 or less.

    if gifts_worth_39_or_less: VAT_not_charged = True #

    You pay VAT when you buy the goods or to the delivery company before you receive them. If you have to pay VAT to the delivery company, it’s charged on the total package value, including:

    #
  • the value of the goods
    • #
  • postage, packaging and insurance
    • #
  • any duty you owe
    • VAT_payment_required = True #

    VAT is charged at the VAT rate that applies to your goods.

    VAT_charged_at_applicable_rate = True #

    Goods worth £135 or less in total

    #

    If you bought the goods yourself and they are not excise goods, the seller will have included VAT in the total you paid.

    if goods_worth_135_or_less and not_excise_goods: VAT_included_in_total_paid = True #

    You will need to pay VAT to the delivery company if the goods are:

    #
  • gifts sent to you by someone else and worth more than £39
    • #
  • excise goods
    • if gifts_over_39 or excise_goods: VAT_payment_to_delivery_company_required = True #

    Customs Duty

    #

    You’ll be charged Customs Duty on all goods sent from outside the UK (or the UK and the EU if you’re in Northern Ireland) if they’re either:

    #
  • excise goods
    • #
  • worth more than £135
    • if sent_from_outside_UK_or_UK_and_EU_to_Northern_Ireland or worth_more_than_135: Customs_Duty_charged = True #

    If you’re charged Customs Duty, you’ll need to pay it on both:

    #
  • the price paid for the goods

#

Overview

#

When a company is dissolved, all of its assets pass to the Crown and are legally known as ‘bona vacantia’ (ownerless property). Assets include:

company_dissolved = True assets_pass_to_crown = True assets_include = [ "property and land", "mortgages", "shares", "intellectual property, for example trademarks, registered designs and patents" ] #

Apply for a discretionary grant

#

You may be able to get back a dissolved company’s assets if you were one of its shareholders.

if shareholder_of_dissolved_company: eligible_for_discretionary_grant = True #

How to apply

#

In England and Wales (but not Cornwall or Lancashire) you must apply to the Treasury Solicitor.

apply_to_treasury_solicitor = True #

How you apply depends on whether the company can be restored or not.

if company_can_be_restored: apply_for_restoration = True else: apply_for_non_restoration = True #

The Treasury Solicitor has guidance on what you should do if:

#
  • the company can be restored
    • if company_can_be_restored: treasury_solicitor_guidance_for_restoration = True #
  • the company cannot be restored
    • else: treasury_solicitor_guidance_for_non_restoration = True
inter_results.full_response:
#

You may be able to get back a dissolved company’s assets if you were one of its shareholders.

    It’s paid every 4 weeks and there’s no limit to how many children you can claim for.

    This guide is also available in Welsh (Cymraeg).

    guide_available_in_welsh = True #

  • you can get National Insurance credits which count towards your State Pension
    • get_national_insurance_credits = True #
  • your child will automatically get a National Insurance number when they’re 16 years old
    • child_gets_national_insurance_number_at_16 = True #

    If you choose not to get Child Benefit payments, you should still fill in and send off the claim form.

    if choose_not_to_get_child_benefit_payments: still_fill_and_send_claim_form = True #

Overview

#

Anything posted or couriered to you from another country goes through customs to check it is not banned or restricted and you pay the right tax and ‘duty’ on it.

goods_posted_or_couriered_from_another_country = True #

This includes anything new or used that you:

if buy_online or buy_abroad_and_send_to_UK or receive_as_gift: includes_new_or_used_goods = True #

Your responsibilities

#

Before receiving your goods, you may have to pay VAT, Customs Duty or Excise Duty if they were sent to:

#
  • Great Britain (England, Wales and Scotland) from outside the UK
    • #
  • Northern Ireland from countries outside the UK and the European Union (EU)
    • if sent_to_Great_Britain_from_outside_UK or sent_to_Northern_Ireland_from_outside_UK_and_EU: may_have_to_pay_VAT_Customs_Duty_or_Excise_Duty = True #

    You must also check that the sender:

    #
  • pays Excise Duty on any alcohol or tobacco sent from the EU to Northern Ireland
    • #
  • declares goods correctly if they’re sent from outside the UK (or from outside the EU for Northern Ireland)
    • if sender_pays_Excise_Duty_on_alcohol_or_tobacco_to_Northern_Ireland_from_EU or sender_declares_goods_correctly_from_outside_UK: must_check_sender_responsibilities = True #

    Your goods may be seized if you do not follow the rules. You may also be fined or prosecuted.

    if do_not_follow_rules: goods_may_be_seized = True may_be_fined_or_prosecuted = True #

    Tax and duty

    #

    You’ll be contacted by Royal Mail, Parcelforce or the courier company if you need to pay any VAT, duty or delivery charges (‘handling fees’) to receive your goods.

    contacted_by_delivery_company_to_pay_VAT_duty_or_delivery_charges = True #

    They’ll send you a bill stating exactly which fees you need to pay.

    bill_sent_stating_fees_to_pay = True #

    They’ll normally hold your parcel for about 3 weeks. If you have not paid the bill by then, your parcel will be returned to the sender.

    parcel_held_for_3_weeks = True if not_paid_bill_by_3_weeks: parcel_returned_to_sender = True #

    You will not have to pay anything to the delivery company to receive goods worth less than £135 unless they’re gifts over £39 or excise goods (for example, alcohol and tobacco).

    if goods_worth_less_than_135: no_payment_to_delivery_company_required = True if gifts_over_39 or excise_goods: payment_to_delivery_company_required = True #

    Excise Duty

    #

    If you’re sent alcohol or tobacco from outside the UK, you’ll be charged Excise Duty at current rates.

    if sent_alcohol_or_tobacco_from_outside_UK: charged_Excise_Duty = True #

    if sent_from_EU_to_Northern_Ireland: check_Excise_Duty_included_in_price = True if Excise_Duty_not_included: goods_may_be_seized = True #

    It does not matter whether you buy the goods or they’re sent as a gift.

    buying_goods_or_sent_as_gift = True #

Overview

#

You must register your business for VAT with HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) if its VAT taxable turnover is more than £85,000.

if VAT_taxable_turnover > 85000: register_for_VAT = True #

When you register, you’ll be sent a VAT registration certificate. This confirms:

#
  • your VAT number
    • #
  • when to submit your first VAT Return and payment
    • #
  • your ‘effective date of registration’ - this depends on the date you went over the threshold, or is the date you asked to register if it was voluntary
    • if register_for_VAT: VAT_registration_certificate_sent = True VAT_registration_certificate_details = { "VAT_number": VAT_number, "first_VAT_Return_and_payment_date": first_VAT_Return_and_payment_date, "effective_date_of_registration": effective_date_of_registration } #

    You can register voluntarily if your turnover is less than £85,000, unless everything you sell is exempt. You’ll have certain responsibilities if you register for VAT.

    if turnover < 85000 and not everything_sold_is_exempt: register_for_VAT_voluntarily = True VAT_responsibilities = True #

    You can reclaim the VAT you’ve paid on certain purchases made before you registered.

    if purchases_made_before_registration: can_reclaim_VAT_paid_on_purchases = True #

    You can ask HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) to cancel your registration if your VAT taxable turnover falls below the deregistration threshold of £83,000.

#

#

You can ask HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) to cancel your registration if your VAT taxable turnover falls below the deregistration threshold of £83,000.

business_type = "salon"
annual_revenue = 30000
vatable_threshold = 85000
vat_registration_required = None # This is the variable that answers the question
inter_results.doc_code:
#

Overview

#

You must register your business for VAT with HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) if its VAT taxable turnover is more than £85,000.

if VAT_taxable_turnover > 85000: register_for_VAT = True #

When you register, you’ll be sent a VAT registration certificate. This confirms:

#
  • your VAT number
    • #
  • when to submit your first VAT Return and payment
    • #
  • your ‘effective date of registration’ - this depends on the date you went over the threshold, or is the date you asked to register if it was voluntary
    • if register_for_VAT: VAT_registration_certificate_sent = True VAT_registration_certificate_details = { "VAT_number": VAT_number, "first_VAT_Return_and_payment_date": first_VAT_Return_and_payment_date, "effective_date_of_registration": effective_date_of_registration } #

    You can register voluntarily if your turnover is less than £85,000, unless everything you sell is exempt. You’ll have certain responsibilities if you register for VAT.

    if turnover < 85000 and not everything_sold_is_exempt: voluntary_registration_possible = True responsibilities_with_VAT_registration = True #

    You can reclaim the VAT you’ve paid on certain purchases made before you registered.

    if purchases_made_before_registration: VAT_reclaim_possible = True #

    When to register

    #

    You must register for VAT if your VAT taxable turnover goes over £85,000 (the ‘threshold’), or you know that it will. Your VAT taxable turnover is the total of everything sold that is not VAT exempt.

    if VAT_taxable_turnover > 85000 or know_will_exceed_threshold: must_register_for_VAT = True #

    You can also register voluntarily.

    if voluntary_registration_possible: voluntary_registration = True #

    If you’ll exceed the VAT threshold in the next 30-day period

    #

    You must register if you realise that your total VAT taxable turnover is going to be more than £85,000 in the next 30-day period.

    #

    You have to register by the end of that 30-day period. Your effective date of registration is the date you realised, not the date your turnover went over the threshold.

    if realise_will_exceed_threshold_in_next_30_days: must_register_within_30_days = True effective_date_of_registration = date_realised #

    If you exceeded the VAT threshold in the past 12 months

    #

    You must register if, by the end of any month, your total VAT taxable turnover for the last 12 months was over £85,000.

    #

    You have to register within 30 days of the end of the month when you went over the threshold. Your effective date of registration is the first day of the second month after you go over the threshold.

    if VAT_taxable_turnover_exceeded_in_past_12_months: must_register_within_30_days = True effective_date_of_registration = first_day_of_second_month_after_exceeding_threshold #

    If you sell goods or services that are VAT exempt and are based in Northern Ireland

    #

    You’ll need to register if you only sell goods or services that are exempt from VAT or ‘out of scope’ but you buy goods for more than £85,000 from EU VAT-registered suppliers to use in your business.

    if sell_goods_or_services_exempt_and_based_in_Northern_Ireland and buy_goods_for_more_than_85000_from_EU_VAT_registered_suppliers: need_to_register_for_VAT = True #

    If you take over a VAT-registered business

    #

    You may have to register for VAT.

    if take_over_VAT_registered_business: may_have_to_register_for_VAT = True #

    Businesses outside the UK

    #

    There’s no threshold if neither you nor your business is based in the UK. You must register as soon as you supply any goods and services to the UK (or if you expect to in the next 30 days).

    if business_outside_UK: no_threshold_for_registration = True register_when_supply_goods_or_services_to_UK = True #

    Voluntary registration

    #

    You can register voluntarily if your business turnover is below £85,000. You must pay HMRC any VAT you owe from the date they register you.

    if voluntary_registration: pay_VAT_from_registration_date = True
inter_results.full_response:
#

You can register voluntarily if your turnover is less than £85,000, unless everything you sell is exempt. You’ll have certain responsibilities if you register for VAT.

#

You can also register voluntarily.

#

When to register

#

You must register for VAT if your VAT taxable turnover goes over £85,000 (the ‘threshold’), or you know that it will. Your VAT taxable turnover is the total of everything sold that is not VAT exempt.

#

You can register voluntarily if your business turnover is below £85,000. You must pay HMRC any VAT you owe from the date they register you.

bachelors_degree_in_computer_science = True
years_since_graduation = 2
continue_education = True
masters_degree = True
applied_for_loan = True
loan_money_allocation = None # This is the variable that answers the question
inter_results.doc_code:
#

Overview

#

A Postgraduate Master’s Loan can help with course fees and living costs while you study a postgraduate master’s course.

postgraduate_masters_loan_available = True #

Funding for postgraduate loans is different if:

#
  • you normally live in Scotland
    • if normally_live_in_scotland: funding_different_for_scotland = True #
  • you normally live in Wales
    • if normally_live_in_wales: funding_different_for_wales = True #
  • you normally live in Northern Ireland.
    • if normally_live_in_northern_ireland: funding_different_for_northern_ireland = True #

    Moving somewhere to study does not count as normally living there.

    moving_to_study_not_counted_as_normal_living = True #

    You can also get extra support if you have a disability.

    extra_support_for_disability_available = True #

    You will not be eligible for an Adult Dependants’ Grant, a Childcare Grant or Parents’ Learning Allowance from Student Finance England if you’re studying a master’s course.

    not_eligible_for_additional_grants_from_Student_Finance_England = True #

    What you'll get

    #

    You can get up to:

    #
  • £11,570 if your course starts on or after 1 August 2021
    • if course_starts_on_or_after_1_august_2021: loan_amount = 11570 #
  • £11,222 if your course started between 1 August 2020 and 31 July 2021
    • elif course_started_between_1_august_2020_and_31_july_2021: loan_amount = 11222 #
  • £10,906 if your course started between 1 August 2019 and 31 July 2020
    • elif course_started_between_1_august_2019_and_31_july_2020: loan_amount = 10906 #

    The amount you’ll get is not based on your income or your family’s.

    loan_amount_not_based_on_income = True #

    The Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) may take account of the loan when working out any benefits you receive.

    DWP_may_take_loan_into_account_for_benefit_calculations = True #

    The loan is paid directly to you. You can use it for your course fees and living costs.

    loan_paid_directly_to_you = True use_loan_for_course_fees_and_living_costs = True #

    If your course lasts for more than a year, the loan will be divided equally across each year of your course.

    if course_lasts_more_than_a_year: loan_divided_equally_across_years = True

The loan is paid directly to you. You can use it for your course fees and living costs.

Who needs to take training

#

Compulsory basic training (CBT) is a course you usually have to take before you ride a moped or motorcycle on the road.

CBT_required_before_riding_moped_or_motorcycle = True #

The training makes sure you can ride safely on your own while you practise for your full moped or motorcycle test.

CBT_ensures_safety_while_practising_for_full_test = True #

CBT is not a test that you pass or fail.

CBT_not_pass_or_fail_test = True #

After you’ve completed CBT, you can ride a:

#
  • moped if you’re 16 or over
    • #
  • motorcycle up to 125cc and with a power output of up to 11kW if you’re 17 or over
    • if completed_CBT: can_ride_moped_at_16_or_over = True can_ride_motorcycle_up_to_125cc_and_11kW_at_17_or_over = True #

    You must use L plates (L or D plates in Wales).

    must_use_L_plates = True #

    You must pass your full moped or motorcycle test within 2 years, or you have to either take CBT again or stop riding.

    if not_pass_full_test_within_2_years: must_retake_CBT_or_stop_riding = True #

    You can be fined up to £1,000 and get up to 6 penalty points for riding if you do not have a valid CBT certificate.

    if do_not_have_valid_CBT_certificate: can_be_fined_up_to_1000 = True can_get_up_to_6_penalty_points = True #

    Preparing for your CBT course

    #

    Your trainer can stop your compulsory basic training (CBT) course if your basic knowledge of The Highway Code and traffic signs is not good enough for you to ride safely.

    if basic_knowledge_of_Highway_Code_and_traffic_signs_not_good_enough: trainer_can_stop_CBT_course = True #

    You need to know:

# Question: I own a newly built house and I have set up a septic tank since the property is not connected to the main public sewer. It is mainly for domestic purposes from a toilet and kitchen. Do I need to apply for a permit or a licence to own it?
newly_built_house = True

property_not_connected_to_public_sewer = True
domestic_purposes_only = True
permit_required = None # This is the variable that answers the question
inter_results.doc_code:
#

Overview

#

If your house or business is not connected to the mains sewer, your sewage will go to one of the following:

if not_connected_to_mains_sewer: #
  • a septic tank - an underground tank where the solids sink to the bottom and the liquid flows out and soaks through the ground
    • septic_tank_used = True #
  • a small sewage treatment plant (also known as a package treatment plant) - a part-mechanical system that treats the liquid so it’s clean enough to go into a river or stream
    • small_sewage_treatment_plant_used = True #
  • a cesspool (also called a cesspit) - a sealed tank that collects the sewage
    • cesspool_used = True #
  • a non-standard system, such as a reed bed or trench arch system
    • non_standard_system_used = True #

    There are different rules for septic tanks and treatment plants in Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales.

    septic_tank_and_treatment_plant_rules_differ_in_NI_Scotland_Wales = True #

    You have a septic tank or small sewage treatment plant

    #

    As the ‘operator’ of a septic tank or small sewage treatment plant you must check you meet the general binding rules. You must apply for a permit if you do not.

    if septic_tank_used or small_sewage_treatment_plant_used: operator_of_system = True check_compliance_with_general_binding_rules = True apply_for_permit_if_not_compliant = True #

    You’re an operator if any of the following is true:

    if operator_of_system: #
  • you own the property that uses the system
    • own_property_using_system = True #
  • you own a property that shares the system with other properties - each property owner is an operator, and you’re jointly responsible for complying with the general binding rules
    • own_property_sharing_system = True #
  • you have a written agreement with the property owner that says you’re responsible for the system’s maintenance, for example you’re renting and it’s in your tenancy agreement
    • written_agreement_responsible_for_maintenance = True #

    Contact the Environment Agency if you’re not sure whether you’re an operator.

    if not_sure_operator: contact_environment_agency = True #

    The general binding rules

    #

    You must follow the general binding rules if you’re the operator of a septic tank or small sewage treatment plant.

    if operator_of_system: follow_general_binding_rules = True #

    The sewage must:

    #
  • be domestic in nature, for example from a toilet, bathroom, shower or kitchen of a house, flat or business (such as a pub, hotel or office) - contact the Environment Agency if you’re not sure if the sewage is domestic in nature
    • #
  • not cause pollution - find out how to check for pollution
    • sewage_requirements = [ "sewage must be domestic in nature", "sewage must not cause pollution" ] #

    There are other rules depending on whether you’re releasing this sewage:

    #
  • to the ground, for example in your back garden
    • #
  • to a surface water, for example a river or stream
    • sewage_release_rules = [ "rules for releasing sewage to the ground", "rules for releasing sewage to a surface water" ] #

    Ask your local installation or maintenance company if you’re not sure what sort of system you have.

    if not_sure_system_type: ask_local_installation_or_maintenance_company = True #

    Apply for a permit

    #

    You’ll need a permit if you do not meet the general binding rules.

    if not_compliant_with_general_binding_rules: permit_required = True #

    The form you need to fill in depends on:

    #
  • where you discharge the sewage
    • #
  • how much you discharge

#

Your rights and responsibilities

#

You have certain rights and responsibilities if you’re a tenant in privately rented property.

tenant_in_privately_rented_property = True #

What your landlord must do

#

Your landlord is always responsible for repairs to:

#
  • the property’s structure and exterior
    • landlord_responsible_for_structure_and_exterior = True #
  • basins, sinks, baths and other sanitary fittings including pipes and drains
    • landlord_responsible_for_sanitary_fittings = True #
  • heating and hot water
    • landlord_responsible_for_heating_and_hot_water = True #
  • gas appliances, pipes, flues and ventilation
    • landlord_responsible_for_gas_appliances = True #
  • electrical wiring
    • landlord_responsible_for_electrical_wiring = True #
  • any damage they cause by attempting repairs
    • landlord_responsible_for_damage_caused_by_repairs = True #

    Your landlord is usually responsible for repairing common areas, for example staircases in blocks of flats. Check your tenancy agreement if you’re unsure.

    landlord_responsible_for_common_areas = True #

    If your property needs repairs

    #

    Contact your landlord if you think repairs are needed. Do this straight away for faults that could damage health, for example faulty electrical wiring.

    if repairs_needed: contact_landlord_for_repairs = True #

    Your landlord should tell you when you can expect the repairs to be done. You should carry on paying rent while you’re waiting.

    landlord_should_provide_repair_timeline = True continue_paying_rent_while_waiting_for_repairs = True #

    Coronavirus has not changed these rules, so you should work with your landlord to make sure that any urgent repairs happen safely. Follow NHS guidelines if the repair must happen.

    coronavirus_not_changed_rules = True work_with_landlord_for_urgent_repairs = True follow_NHS_guidelines_for_repairs = True #

    If repairs are not done

    #

    Contact the environmental health department at your local council for help. They must take action if they think the problems could harm you or cause a nuisance to others.

    if repairs_not_done: contact_environmental_health_department = True action_taken_by_environmental_health_department = True #

    Contact the Private Rented Housing Panel (PRHP) if you’re in Scotland.

    if in_scotland: contact_PRHP = True #

    If your house is not fit to live in

    #

    If you think your home’s unsafe, contact housing department at your local council. They’ll do a Housing Health and Safety Rating System (HHSRS) assessment and must take action if they think your home has serious health and safety hazards.

    if house_not_fit_to_live_in: contact_housing_department = True HHSRS_assessment_done = True action_taken_by_housing_department = True #

    There are different:

    #
  • housing standards and procedures in Scotland
    • different_housing_standards_in_scotland = True #
  • housing standards and procedures in Northern Ireland
    • different_housing_standards_in_northern_ireland = True

Search for an adviser

#

You can get immigration advice from an immigration adviser if you need help with getting permission to stay in the UK.

need_immigration_advice = True #

Immigration advisers can help you with most things to do with immigration, including helping you to fill in the right forms and representing you at a tribunal. They do not make immigration decisions.

immigration_advisers_can_help_with_forms_and_representation = True immigration_advisers_do_not_make_immigration_decisions = True #

Check if the adviser is registered and if they charge a fee before you use them.

check_adviser_registration = True check_adviser_fee = True #

If you’re an EU citizen and you were living in the UK by 31 December 2020, you can apply to the EU Settlement Scheme to continue living here after 30 June 2021. If you want to move to the UK from 1 January 2021, you may need to apply for a visa.

if EU_citizen and living_in_UK_by_31_December_2020: apply_to_EU_Settlement_Scheme = True if moving_to_UK_from_1_January_2021: may_need_to_apply_for_visa = True #

Find a registered immigration adviser

#

Use the Office of the Immigration Services Commissioner (OISC) Adviser Finder to find a registered adviser near you.

use_OISC_Adviser_Finder = True #

All immigration advisers must be registered with OISC or be a member of an approved professional body, for example The Law Society.

immigration_advisers_must_be_registered_with_OISC = True immigration_advisers_can_be_member_of_approved_professional_body = True

How it works

#

You get Child Benefit if you’re responsible for bringing up a child who is:

  • under 16
    • #
  • under 20 if they stay in approved education or training
    • if responsible_for_bringing_up_child: get_child_benefit = True child_under_16 = True child_under_20_in_approved_education_or_training = True #

    Only one person can get Child Benefit for a child.

    only_one_person_get_child_benefit = True #

    It’s paid every 4 weeks and there’s no limit to how many children you can claim for.

    child_benefit_paid_every_4_weeks = True no_limit_on_number_of_children_claimed_for = True #

    This guide is also available in Welsh (Cymraeg).

    guide_available_in_welsh = True #

    By claiming Child Benefit:

    #
  • you can get National Insurance credits which count towards your State Pension
    • get_national_insurance_credits = True #
  • your child will automatically get a National Insurance number when they’re 16 years old
    • child_gets_national_insurance_number_at_16 = True #

    If you choose not to get Child Benefit payments, you should still fill in and send off the claim form.

    if choose_not_to_get_child_benefit_payments: still_fill_and_send_claim_form = True #

    If you or your partner earn over £50,000

    #

    You may have to pay back some of your Child Benefit in tax if your (or your partner’s) individual income is over £50,000.

    if individual_income_over_50000: may_have_to_pay_back_child_benefit_in_tax = True #

    If you or your partner earn over £50,000

    #

    You can get Child Benefit if your (or your partner’s) individual income is over £50,000, but you may be taxed on the benefit. This is known as the High Income Child Benefit Tax Charge.

    if individual_income_over_50000: get_child_benefit = True may_be_taxed_on_benefit = True high_income_child_benefit_tax_charge = True #

    If your partner’s income is also over £50,000 but yours is higher, you’re responsible for paying the tax charge. You need to fill in a Self Assessment tax return each tax year and pay what you owe.

    if partner_income_over_50000 and your_income_higher: responsible_for_paying_tax_charge = True fill_in_self_assessment_tax_return = True #

    Use the Child Benefit tax calculator to estimate how much tax you may have to pay.

Would we still receive any sort of benefit if we are both working full time? partner_has_second_child = True partner_wants_to_go_back_to_work = True no_time_off = True both_working_full_time = True eligible_for_benefits = Null # This variable is the answer to the question # Document: #

    How it works

    #

    You and your partner may be able to get Shared Parental Leave (SPL) and Statutory Shared Parental Pay (ShPP) if you’re:

  • having a baby

    maximum_leave_weeks_is_50 = True maximum_pay_weeks_is_37 = True #

    SPL_blocks = True SPL_one_go = True SPL_together_or_stagger = True #

    To get SPL and ShPP, you and your partner need to:

    #

    • #

How it works

#

You get Child Benefit if you’re responsible for bringing up a child who is:

#
  • under 16

Therefore, we requested from our employer an information and consultation agreement. He instantly denied as if he was anticipating such a moment and stated that there are pre-existing agreements to which we have all agreed to. We checked the contracts we have signed and while about 10% of us have signed such an agreement the others have not.. Who can we complain to under these circumstances?
employees_count = None # Number of employees in the company
worried_about_finances = True
requested_information_consultation_agreement = True
employer_denied_request = True
pre_existing_agreements = True
signed_agreement_count = None # Number of employees who have signed the agreement
complain_to = None # This is the variable that answers the question
inter_results.doc_code:
#

Overview

#

You, together with other employees, can ask your employer to keep you informed and consult with you on issues related to your company or organisation.

employees_can_ask_employer_to_keep_informed_and_consult = True #

This may include:

#
  • the company or organisation’s performance, for example financially and competitively
    • keep_informed_and_consult_on_company_performance = True #
  • any changes to your working conditions and employment prospects
    • keep_informed_and_consult_on_working_conditions_and_employment_prospects = True #

    This is called an information and consultation agreement.

    information_and_consultation_agreement = True #

    Your employer can start negotiating an agreement without a request from its employees.

    employer_can_start_negotiating_agreement_without_request = True #

    Pre-existing agreements

    #

    Your employer may say there’s already an agreement about keeping you informed and consulting you.

    pre_existing_agreement_possible = True #

    A pre-existing agreement is a written explanation of how the employer informs and consults employees or representatives. It must:

    #
  • cover all employees
    • pre_existing_agreement_covers_all_employees = True #
  • have been agreed by those employees
    • pre_existing_agreement_agreed_by_employees = True #

    You can complain to CAC if you do not agree there’s a pre-existing agreement.

    complain_to_CAC_if_no_agreement = True
inter_results.full_response:
#

You can complain to CAC if you do not agree there’s a pre-existing agreement.

# Answer: CAC

Mediation

Mediation is when an independent, impartial third party discusses a problem with you and your employer (or between you and another employee) to try and find a solution. It’s often used after informal discussions have not solved the issue.

# Document: #

Overview

#

You must apply for asylum if you want to stay in the UK as a refugee.

apply_for_asylum = True #

To be eligible you must have left your country and be unable to go back because you fear persecution.

eligible_for_asylum = True left_country_due_to_fear_of_persecution = True #

Apply for a visa if you want to come to the UK for another reason (for example to work, study or remain with family). If you’re already in the UK and want to remain with family living here, apply for a family of a settled person visa.

apply_for_visa_for_other_reasons = True apply_for_family_of_settled_person_visa = True #

You should apply when you arrive in the UK or as soon as you think it would be unsafe for you to return to your own country. Your application is more likely to be denied if you wait.

apply_for_asylum_when_arrive_or_unsafe_to_return = True application_more_likely_to_be_denied_if_wait = True #

When you apply you’ll have a meeting with an immigration officer (known as a ‘screening’).

meeting_with_immigration_officer = True meeting_known_as_screening = True #

After your screening the Home Office will decide if your claim can be considered in the UK. If it can, you’ll have an asylum interview with a caseworker.

claim_considered_in_UK_after_screening = True asylum_interview_with_caseworker = True #

You’ll usually get a decision on your application within 6 months.

decision_within_6_months = True #

You can get up to 2 years in prison or have to leave the UK if you give false information on your application.

if give_false_information_on_application: punishment_up_to_2_years_in_prison = True may_have_to_leave_UK = True #

Your ARC

#

The ARC shows you’ve applied for asylum. You can use it to:

#
  • show who you are
    • show_identity_with_ARC = True #
  • show whether you have permission to work
    • show_permission_to_work_with_ARC = True #
  • get health or education services
    • get_health_or_education_services_with_ARC = True #

    You must take your ARC with you when you go to your reporting meetings.

    take_ARC_to_reporting_meetings = True

Overview

#

You must apply for asylum if you want to stay in the UK as a refugee.

apply_for_visa_for_other_reasons = True apply_for_family_of_settled_person_visa = True #

You should apply when you arrive in the UK or as soon as you think it would be unsafe for you to return to your own country. Your application is more likely to be denied if you wait.

apply_as_soon_as_possible = True #

When you apply you’ll have a meeting with an immigration officer (known as a ‘screening’).

screening_meeting_with_immigration_officer = True #

After your screening the Home Office will decide if your claim can be considered in the UK. If it can, you’ll have an asylum interview with a caseworker.

claim_considered_in_UK = True asylum_interview_with_caseworker = True #

You’ll usually get a decision on your application within 6 months.

decision_within_6_months = True #

if give_false_information: consequences = "up to 2 years in prison or have to leave the UK" #

Eligibility

To stay in the UK as a refugee you must be unable to live safely in any part of your own country because you fear persecution there.

unable_to_live_safely_in_own_country = True fear_persecution_in_own_country = True #

If you’re stateless, your own country is the country you usually live in.

if stateless: own_country = country_you_usually_live_in #

    You must have failed to get protection from authorities in your own country.

    failed_to_get_protection_from_authorities = True #

Overview

#

A Postgraduate Master’s Loan can help with course fees and living costs while you study a postgraduate master’s course.

postgraduate_masters_loan_available = True #

Funding for postgraduate loans is different if:

#
  • you normally live in Scotland
    • if normally_live_in_scotland: funding_different_for_scotland = True #
  • you normally live in Wales
    • if normally_live_in_wales: funding_different_for_wales = True #

    • if normally_live_in_northern_ireland: funding_different_for_northern_ireland = True #

    Moving somewhere to study does not count as normally living there.

    if studying_masters_course: not_eligible_for_grants_from_Student_Finance_England = True #

    Proof of identity

    #

    Include valid UK passport details in your application. Use the ‘UK passport details’ form if you need to send the details after your application. Do not send the passport itself.

    include_valid_UK_passport_details = True use_UK_passport_details_form = True do_not_send_passport_itself = True #

    If you do not have a UK passport (or it has expired), send your original birth or adoption certificate to Student Finance England.

    include_name_and_address = True include_customer_reference_number = True #

    If you’re an EU national, send your passport or national identity card.

    if EU_national: send_passport_or_national_identity_card = True

#

Overview

#

As an employer operating PAYE as part of your payroll, you need to complete certain tasks during each tax month. Tax months run from the 6th of one month to the 5th of the next.

employer_operating_PAYE = True tasks_to_complete_in_each_tax_month = True tax_month_start_date = 6 tax_month_end_date = 5 #

You must tell HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) if you’ve not paid any employees in a tax month.

if not_paid_employees_in_tax_month: inform_HMRC = True #

Late reporting

#

HMRC will send you a late filing notice if you’ve paid any employees and do not send an FPS or send one late. They can also charge you a penalty, unless you have a valid reason for reporting late.

if paid_employees_and_no_FPS_sent_or_sent_late: late_filing_notice_sent = True penalty_charged = True valid_reason_for_reporting_late = False #

Late, missing or incorrect payroll reports can also affect your employees’ income-related benefits, such as Universal Credit.

late_missing_or_incorrect_payroll_reports_affect_benefits = True #

HMRC will close your PAYE scheme if you’re a new employer and you do not send a report to or pay HMRC in 120 days.

if new_employer_and_no_report_or_payment_to_HMRC_in_120_days: PAYE_scheme_closed = True

# Question: I am looking at doing master's course in the UK. It is an Msc course that is eligible for a postgraduate loan. I do not know how much the loan is.. How much funding is available for a postgraduate student for my course which started on the 10th of September 2020?
course_type = "Msc"
eligible_for_postgraduate_loan = True
course_start_date = "10th September 2020"

inter_results.doc_code:
#

Overview

#

A Postgraduate Master’s Loan can help with course fees and living costs while you study a postgraduate master’s course.

postgraduate_masters_loan_available = True #

Funding for postgraduate loans is different if:

#
  • you normally live in Scotland
    • if normally_live_in_scotland: funding_different_for_scotland = True #
  • you normally live in Wales
    • if normally_live_in_wales: funding_different_for_wales = True #
  • you normally live in Northern Ireland.
    • if normally_live_in_northern_ireland: funding_different_for_northern_ireland = True #

    Moving somewhere to study does not count as normally living there.

    moving_to_study_not_counted_as_normal_living = True #

    You can also get extra support if you have a disability.

    extra_support_for_disability_available = True #

    You will not be eligible for an Adult Dependants’ Grant, a Childcare Grant or Parents’ Learning Allowance from Student Finance England if you’re studying a master’s course.

    not_eligible_for_additional_grants_from_Student_Finance_England = True #

    What you'll get

    #

    #
  • £11,570 if your course starts on or after 1 August 2021

  • £11,222 if your course started between 1 August 2020 and 31 July 2021
    • elif course_started_between_1_august_2020_and_31_july_2021: loan_amount = 11222 #
  • £10,906 if your course started between 1 August 2019 and 31 July 2020
    • elif course_started_between_1_august_2019_and_31_july_2020: loan_amount = 10906 #

    The amount you’ll get is not based on your income or your family’s.

    loan_amount_not_based_on_income = True #

    The Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) may take account of the loan when working out any benefits you receive.

    DWP_may_take_loan_into_account_for_benefit_calculations = True #

    The loan is paid directly to you. You can use it for your course fees and living costs.

    loan_paid_directly_to_you = True use_loan_for_course_fees_and_living_costs = True #

    If your course lasts for more than a year, the loan will be divided equally across each year of your course.

    if course_lasts_more_than_a_year: loan_divided_equally_across_years = True

When your landlord can increase rent

  • a small sewage treatment plant (also known as a package treatment plant) - a part-mechanical system that treats the liquid so it’s clean enough to go into a river or stream
    • small_sewage_treatment_plant_used = True #
  • a cesspool (also called a cesspit) - a sealed tank that collects the sewage
    • cesspool_used = True #
  • a non-standard system, such as a reed bed or trench arch system
    • non_standard_system_used = True #

    different_rules_in_northern_ireland = True different_rules_in_scotland = True different_rules_in_wales = True #

CBT is not a test that you pass or fail.

After you’ve completed CBT, you can ride a:

  • moped if you’re 16 or over

# Question: I am a 20 year old refugee who has attempted to claim asylum in the UK. At the screening, I have been told that my case may not be able to be considered. The Home Office have stated that they cannot put me in another safe country.. What happens if my case cannot be considered?
age = 20
refugee = True
claim_asylum = True
case_cannot_be_considered = True
home_office_cannot_put_in_safe_country = True
outcome_if_case_cannot_be_considered = None # This is the variable that answers the question
inter_results.doc_code:
#

Overview

#

You must apply for asylum if you want to stay in the UK as a refugee.

apply_for_asylum = True #

To be eligible you must have left your country and be unable to go back because you fear persecution.

if left_country_and_fear_persecution: eligible_for_asylum = True #

Apply for a visa if you want to come to the UK for another reason (for example to work, study or remain with family). If you’re already in the UK and want to remain with family living here, apply for a family of a settled person visa.

apply_for_visa_for_other_reasons = True apply_for_family_of_settled_person_visa = True #

You should apply when you arrive in the UK or as soon as you think it would be unsafe for you to return to your own country. Your application is more likely to be denied if you wait.

apply_for_asylum_when_arrive_or_unsafe_to_return = True #

When you apply you’ll have a meeting with an immigration officer (known as a ‘screening’).

screening_meeting_with_immigration_officer = True #

After your screening the Home Office will decide if your claim can be considered in the UK. If it can, you’ll have an asylum interview with a caseworker.

if claim_can_be_considered_in_UK: asylum_interview_with_caseworker = True #

You’ll usually get a decision on your application within 6 months.

decision_within_6_months = True #

You can get up to 2 years in prison or have to leave the UK if you give false information on your application.

if give_false_information_on_application: punishment_up_to_2_years_in_prison_or_leave_UK = True #

If your case cannot be considered in the UK

#

You may be sent to a safe country that will consider your asylum claim. This might happen if you’ve travelled to the UK through a safe third country or you have a connection with another country that you could claim asylum in.

if case_cannot_be_considered_in_UK: sent_to_safe_country = True #

Generally, a safe country is one that:

#
  • you’re not a citizen of
    • #
  • you would not be harmed in
    • #
  • would not send you on to another country where you would be harmed
    • safe_country_conditions = [ "not a citizen of", "would not be harmed in", "would not send you on to another country where you would be harmed" ] #

    The Home Office can decide to send you to a safe country after either your screening or your asylum interview.

    if send_to_safe_country_after_screening_or_asylum_interview: decision_to_send_to_safe_country = True #

    If the Home Office cannot place you in another safe country, your case will be considered in the UK and given to a caseworker.

    if cannot_place_in_another_safe_country: case_considered_in_UK = True
inter_results.full_response:
#

If the Home Office cannot place you in another safe country, your case will be considered in the UK and given to a caseworker.

# Answer: your case will be considered in the UK and given to a caseworker.
